content-id=\"TFN009\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Redshift from the low-<em>J</em> CO lines.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN010\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN010\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>CO line full width half-maximum (FWHM) velocity.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN011\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN011\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Integrated CO line intensity (<em>I</em><sub>CO</sub> = \u222b<em>S</em><sub>CO</sub>d<em>v</em>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN012\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN012\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Observed CO line luminosity in units of <em>l</em><sub>0</sub> = (\u00d7 10<sup>11</sup> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN013\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN013\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>e</em></sup>Continuum flux at the observed frequency \u03bd<sub>cont</sub>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN014\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN014\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>f</em></sup>Velocity difference between the two line peaks is given instead of CO FWHM.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN015\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN015\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>g</em></sup>Observed properties taken from Aravena et\u00a0al. 1.6\u00a0</td><td>4.6 \u00b1 2.4\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.9 \u00b1 0.3\u00a0</td><td>1.1\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN016\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN016\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Source name.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN017\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN017\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Magnification factor obtained through visibility-based lens modelling of ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm continuum imaging data at 0.5\u00a0arcsec resolution (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span>2013).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN018\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN018\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>CO-derived magnification factor, computed using the following relation: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu _{\\rm CO}=3\\times (L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}/10^{11})(\\Delta v_{\\rm FWHM}/400)^{-2.3}$|\u2060</span>, where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> is the measured CO luminosity in units of (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>) and \u0394<em>v</em><sub>FWHM</sub> is the measured linewidth at FWHM in km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. See Section 4.2.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN019\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN019\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Dust properties derived from multiwavelength SED fitting. The parameters listed here have not been corrected for lensing magnification.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN020\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN020\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>e</em></sup>Gas mass derived from the observed CO luminosity assuming \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8, and divided by the lensing magnification \u03bc where available. A typical value of \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a010\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05 was used when a lensing model was not available, for SPT0551\u221248 and SPT2332\u221253.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN021\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN021\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>f</em></sup>Dynamical mass estimated from the line FWHM and the lensing derived effective radius (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation), and assuming a virialized spherical geometry as described in the text. No estimate is provided for SPT0125\u221247 given the complex source geometry seen in the source\u2013plane ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm image.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN022\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN022\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>g</em></sup>Dust-derived CO luminosity to gas mass conversion factor, in units \u03b1<sub>0</sub> = M<sub>\u2299</sub> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN023\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN023\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>h</em></sup>Limit to the CO luminosity to gas mass conversion factor based on a maximum dynamical mass.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow 1.6\u00a0</td><td>4.6 \u00b1 2.4\u00a0</td><td>\u2013\u00a0</td><td>0.9 \u00b1 0.3\u00a0</td><td>1.1\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN016\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN016\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Source name.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN017\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN017\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Magnification factor obtained through visibility-based lens modelling of ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm continuum imaging data at 0.5\u00a0arcsec resolution (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span>2013).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN018\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN018\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>CO-derived magnification factor, computed using the following relation: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu _{\\rm CO}=3\\times (L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}/10^{11})(\\Delta v_{\\rm FWHM}/400)^{-2.3}$|\u2060</span>, where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> is the measured CO luminosity in units of (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>) and \u0394<em>v</em><sub>FWHM</sub> is the measured linewidth at FWHM in km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. See Section 4.2.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN019\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN019\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Dust properties derived from multiwavelength SED fitting. The parameters listed here have not been corrected for lensing magnification.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN020\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN020\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>e</em></sup>Gas mass derived from the observed CO luminosity assuming \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8, and divided by the lensing magnification \u03bc where available. A typical value of \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a010\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05 was used when a lensing model was not available, for SPT0551\u221248 and SPT2332\u221253.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN021\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN021\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>f</em></sup>Dynamical mass estimated from the line FWHM and the lensing derived effective radius (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation), and assuming a virialized spherical geometry as described in the text. No estimate is provided for SPT0125\u221247 given the complex source geometry seen in the source\u2013plane ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm image.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN022\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN022\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>g</em></sup>Dust-derived CO luminosity to gas mass conversion factor, in units \u03b1<sub>0</sub> = M<sub>\u2299</sub> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN023\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN023\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>h</em></sup>Limit to the CO luminosity to gas mass conversion factor based on a maximum dynamical mass.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow class=\"module-widget article-top-widget\">\r\n\r\n    \r\n\r\n    \r\n        <div class=\"access-state-logos all-viewports\">\r\n                    </div>\r\n\r\n\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\">\r\n                <h1 class=\"wi-article-title article-title-main\">\r\n                    A survey of the cold molecular gas in gravitationally lensed star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> &gt; 2\r\n<i class='icon-availability_free' title='Free' ></i>                </h1>\r\n                <div class=\"wi-authors\">\r\n                    <div class=\"al-authors-list\">\r\n                            <div class=\"meta-authors--limited\">\r\n                                    <span class=\"al-author-name $(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div microsite-search-term\" type=\"text\" maxlength=\"255\" id=\"MicrositeSearchTerm\" title=\"search input\">\r\n\r\n                            <a href=\"javascript:;\" id=\"MicrositeSearchIcon\" class=\"navbar-search-collapsed\"><a href=\"javascript:;\" class=\"icon-menu_search js_expand-navsearch\"><span class=\"screenreader-text\">Search Menu</span></a></div>\r\n    </div>\r\n</div>\r\n\r\n<input id=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" name=\"hfEnableOupOnlineProductsFeatures\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"False\" />\r\n\r\n<input id=\"routename\" name=\"RouteName\" type=\"hidden\" value=\"mnras\" /> \n    </div>\n\r\n                    </div>\r\n                </div>\r\n            </div>\r\n            <div id=\"ContentTab\" class=\"content active\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget widget-ArticleFulltext widget-instance-OUP_Article_FullText_Widget\">\n        <div class=\"module-widget\">\r\n    <div class=\"widget-items\" data-widgetname=\"ArticleFulltext\">\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92104790 id=\"92104790\" class=\"abstract-title\" >Abstract</h2>\r\n<section class=\"abstract\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using the Australia Telescope Compact Array, we conducted a survey of CO <em>J</em> = 1 \u2212 0 and <em>J</em> = 2 \u2212 1 line emission towards strongly lensed high-redshift dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs) previously discovered with the South Pole Telescope (SPT). Our sample comprises 17 sources that had CO-based spectroscopic redshifts obtained with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array and the Atacama Pathfinder Experiment. We detect all sources with known redshifts in either CO <em>J</em> = 1 \u2212 0 or <em>J</em> = 2 \u2212 1. 12 sources are detected in the 7-mm continuum. The derived CO luminosities imply gas masses in the range (0.5\u201311) \u00d7 10<sup>10</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> and gas depletion time-scales <em>t</em><sub>dep</sub> &lt; 200\u00a0Myr, using a CO to gas mass conversion factor \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)<sup>\u22121</sup>. Combining the CO luminosities and dust masses, along with a fixed gas-to-dust ratio, we derive \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> factors in the range 0.4\u20131.8\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub> (K\u2009km\u2009s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)<sup>\u22121</sup>, similar to what is found in other starbursting systems. We find small scatter in \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> values within the sample, even though inherent variations in the spatial distribution of dust and gas in individual cases could bias the dust-based \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> estimates. We find that lensing magnification factors based on the CO linewidth to luminosity relation (\u03bc<sub>CO</sub>) are highly unreliable, but particularly when \u03bc &lt; 5. Finally, comparison of the gas and dynamical masses suggest that the average molecular gas fraction stays relatively constant at <em>z</em> = 2\u20135 in the SPT DSFG sample.</p></section>                        <div class=\"article-metadata-panel clearfix\"></div>\r\n<div class=\"kwd-group\"><a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: evolution&quot;\">galaxies: evolution</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: formation&quot;\">galaxies: formation</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: high-redshift&quot;\">galaxies: high-redshift</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;galaxies: starburst&quot;\">galaxies: starburst</a>, <a class=\"kwd-part kwd-main\" href=\"javascript:;\" data-keyword=\"&quot;cosmology: observations&quot;\">cosmology: observations</a></div>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92104792 id=\"92104792\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec1>INTRODUCTION</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Panchromatic deep field observations have shown that the cosmic star formation rate (SFR) density decreases by about an order of magnitude from <em>z</em> \u223c 3 to \u223c0 (e.g. Lilly et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib73\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib73\" data-open=\"bib73\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1996</a>; Bouwens et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib15\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib15\" data-open=\"bib15\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Madau &amp; Dickinson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib76\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib76\" data-open=\"bib76\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). An important contributor to the density of star formation at <em>z</em> \u223c 1\u20133 is an abundant population of galaxies with extreme SFRs ranging from 100 to 1000\u00a0M<sub>\u2299</sub>\u00a0yr<sup>\u22121</sup> and large IR luminosities resulting from the re-processing of UV light by the large amounts of dust present. These galaxies have also been termed dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs) or submillimetre galaxies (SMGs), referring to the region of the spectrum in which some of the most luminous examples were initially discovered (e.g. Smail, Ivison &amp; Blain <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib107\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib107\" data-open=\"bib107\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Hughes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib62\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib62\" data-open=\"bib62\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Bertoldi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib7\" data-open=\"bib7\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2000</a>; Borys et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib12\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib12\" data-open=\"bib12\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>). Current observational evidence suggests that they are likely progenitors of local massive early-type galaxies, and they appear to trace large galaxy overdensities at high redshift (Brodwin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib16\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib16\" data-open=\"bib16\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib29\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib29\" data-open=\"bib29\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Viero et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib122\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib122\" data-open=\"bib122\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Aravena et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Amblard et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib2\" data-open=\"bib2\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Capak et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib19\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib19\" data-open=\"bib19\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Toft et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib119\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib119\" data-open=\"bib119\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The primary reservoir of material in the interstellar medium (ISM) of galaxies is cold molecular gas. Large amounts of gas are necessary to sustain the large SFRs in these objects to build up a massive (&gt;10<sup>10</sup> M<sub>\u2299</sub>), luminous (&gt;<em>L</em><sup>\u22c6</sup>) galaxy in &lt;500\u00a0Myr. The main components of the molecular ISM are H<sub>2</sub> and He with a minor fraction of heavier molecules. Given the difficulty to detect H<sub>2</sub> in the ISM, the CO molecule (the second most abundant molecule after H<sub>2</sub>) has been commonly used to study the gaseous phase of the ISM in galaxies. In particular, the lowest rotational transition of CO <em>J</em> = 1 \u2212 0 represents the best studied tracer of the mass and spatial distribution of H<sub>2</sub> in galaxies (Omont <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib85\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib85\" data-open=\"bib85\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Carilli &amp; Walter <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib20\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib20\" data-open=\"bib20\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The CO line emission can also be used to estimate the dynamical mass of the host galaxy, avoiding uncertainties due to differential dust obscuration and possible ionized outflows seen in the optical/near-infrared studies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">CO studies of DSFGs have often focused on the observation of high-<em>J</em> (<em>J</em> \u2265 3) transitions. However, such CO lines trace regions of enhanced star formation or active galactic nuclei activity where high gas excitation is expected (Greve et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib54\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib54\" data-open=\"bib54\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observations of low-<em>J</em> CO line emission in a few unlensed DSFGs at <em>z</em> \u223c 1\u20133 indicate that their gas masses can be 2 \u00d7 larger and up to 3 \u00d7 more spatially extended than expected based on <em>J</em> \u2265 3 CO transitions (e.g. Papadopoulos &amp; Ivison <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib87\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib87\" data-open=\"bib87\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Greve, Ivison &amp; Papadopoulos <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib51\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib51\" data-open=\"bib51\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011c</a>). These results are reflected in the measured brightness temperature line ratios between the CO(3\u22122) and CO(1\u22120) transitions, <em>R</em><sub>31</sub> = <em>T</em><sub>32</sub>/<em>T</em><sub>10</sub>. For local thermodynamic equilibrium (LTE), this ratio is expected to be close to unity; however, variations of the line ratios in individual sources make predictions of the low-<em>J</em> CO transitions unreliable. Most CO(1\u22120) line measurements in distant galaxies, including DSFGs and relatively quiescent star-forming disc galaxies at high redshift, indicate that <em>R</em><sub>31</sub> may be frequently as low as 0.5 with significant source-to-source variations, exemplifying the fact that <em>J</em> &gt; 2 CO emission lines may not necessarily trace the whole extent of the molecular gas or their total dynamical masses in most cases (e.g. Dannerbauer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib33\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib33\" data-open=\"bib33\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Aravena et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Carilli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib21\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib21\" data-open=\"bib21\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Danielson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib32\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib32\" data-open=\"bib32\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Thomson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Sharon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib105\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib105\" data-open=\"bib105\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib106\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib106\" data-open=\"bib106\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Bolatto et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib11\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib11\" data-open=\"bib11\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>; Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib61\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib61\" data-open=\"bib61\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Indeed, CO measurements in different samples of DSFGs show a significant dispersion, with a median <em>R</em><sub>31</sub> = 0.52 \u00b1 0.09 found by Bothwell et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and a mean <em>R</em><sub>31</sub> = 0.86 \u00b1 0.08 by Spilker et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). In the case of luminous high-redshift quasars, the CO emission is found to be in LTE typically out to <em>J</em> = 5 and the distribution of CO emission, including low-<em>J</em> CO, is mostly found to be concentrated in the inner kpc of the host galaxy, although there is evidence that in some cases the CO emission can be aligned with the radio jet axis (e.g. Papadopoulos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib88\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib88\" data-open=\"bib88\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Elbaz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib41\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib41\" data-open=\"bib41\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Emonts et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib42\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib42\" data-open=\"bib42\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Thus, measurements of molecular gas masses based on <em>J</em> \u2265 3 CO transitions become difficult due to the uncertainty in the unknown line ratios.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Since observing low-<em>J</em> CO emission at high redshift is observationally time consuming, current CO studies have focused on the most luminous galaxies or gravitationally lensed objects. Methods have been proposed to measure the gas masses from dust mass determinations based on far-IR and submillimetre continuum observations (Bloemen, Deul &amp; Thaddeus <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib9\" data-open=\"bib9\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>; Israel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib63\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib63\" data-open=\"bib63\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>; Dame, Hartmann &amp; Thaddeus <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib31\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib31\" data-open=\"bib31\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2001</a>; Leroy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Magdis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Magnelli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Scoville et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). This could open an important window to study the fainter galaxies as continuum observations typically require less observing time, particularly in the era of the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA). Ideally, both molecular line and dust observations are required because they can provide independent estimates and together yield tighter constraints on the ISM conditions.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The discovery of a population of rare (<em>n</em> \u223c 0.1\u00a0deg<sup>\u22122</sup>) and extremely bright (<em>S</em><sub>1.4\u2009mm</sub> &gt; 15\u00a0mJy) mm-selected galaxies in a deep, multiband survey over \u223c2500\u00a0deg<sup>2</sup> of sky with the South Pole Telescope (SPT; Carlstrom et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib23\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib23\" data-open=\"bib23\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), or in the several hundred square degree far-infrared surveys carried out with the <em>Herschel Space Observatory</em> (Pilbratt et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib91\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib91\" data-open=\"bib91\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), allows for detailed studies of the ISM properties of DSFGs out to the highest redshifts (Negrello et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib82\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib82\" data-open=\"bib82\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Vieira et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Mocanu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Wardlow et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib126\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib126\" data-open=\"bib126\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Follow-up high-resolution 870\u00a0\u03bcm observations with ALMA of a sample of SPT sources showed these are strongly gravitationally lensed galaxies at high-redshift (Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Vieira et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib121\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib121\" data-open=\"bib121\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Similar observations with the Submillimeter Array in a sample of bright <em>Herschel</em> and <em>Planck</em> sources recently found similar results (Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Ca\u00f1ameras et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib18\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib18\" data-open=\"bib18\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">After the discovery of bright millimetre SPT sources in a systematic and unbiased way, a major quest began in order to characterize their properties and understand their nature. Blind CO spectroscopic observations with ALMA enabled the redshift confirmation of 28 SPT DSFGs, including two of the highest redshift DSFGs in the literature (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). This represents an ideal sample to study the conditions of the ISM in distant galaxies, with most of the galaxies in the SPT sample (\u223c70\u2009per\u2009cent) confirmed at <em>z</em> &gt; 2. Thus, all the ALMA detected CO transitions in the 3-mm band are <em>J</em> \u2265 3 (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Observations of the low-<em>J</em> CO emission are thus necessary to directly trace their molecular gas content and further investigate the nature of these galaxies.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The SPT DSFGs were shown to have large IR luminosities, being &gt;10<sup>12</sup>\u2009<em>L</em><sub>\u2299</sub> for most sources even after correcting for lensing magnification (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Ma et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib74\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib74\" data-open=\"bib74\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>, this work). Stellar mass measurements of a few SPT DSFGs indicate that they are located above the predicted sequence of secularly evolving star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 2\u20133 in the stellar mass versus SFR plane (e.g. Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib28\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib28\" data-open=\"bib28\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Elbaz et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib40\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib40\" data-open=\"bib40\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Noeske et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib84\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib84\" data-open=\"bib84\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Pannella et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib86\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib86\" data-open=\"bib86\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2009</a>; Peng et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib90\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib90\" data-open=\"bib90\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Karim et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib68\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib68\" data-open=\"bib68\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Rodighiero et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib99\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib99\" data-open=\"bib99\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). The high specific SFRs implied therefore suggest that SPT DSFGs are living in an active starburst phase, likely triggered by major mergers.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we present a systematic survey of the low-<em>J</em> CO line emission (<em>J</em> =1\u22120 and 2\u22121) in a sample of gravitationally lensed SPT DSFGs at <em>z</em> = 2\u20136, conducted with the Australia Telescope Compact Array (ATCA). In Section 2, we present our source sample, the ATCA CO data set, lensing models and dust properties that will be used throughout in this study. In Section 3, we show the results obtained from the ATCA observations. In Section 4, we derive physical properties of the SPT DSFGs based on the reported CO line observations (magnifications, sizes, masses). In Section 5, we discuss the possible implications of our results. Finally, Section 6 summarizes the main conclusions from this paper. Hereafter, we adopt a standard \u039bCDM cosmology with <em>H</em><sub>0</sub> = 71\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0Mpc<sup>\u22121</sup>, \u03a9<sub>M</sub> = 0.27 and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\Omega _\\Lambda =0.73$|\u2060</span>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92104802 id=\"92104802\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2>OBSERVATIONS AND DATA</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104803 id=\"92104803\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-1>Sample sources</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Our sample is drawn from the brightest sources discovered at 1.4-mm wavelength in the multiband SPT Sunyaev\u2013Zeldovich survey of the southern sky, for which the spectral indexes from the mm photometry were consistent with DSFGs at high-redshift (for details see Vieira et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib120\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib120\" data-open=\"bib120\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Mocanu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib81\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib81\" data-open=\"bib81\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). For a subset of 26 of these sources, follow-up spectroscopic observations covering the full 3-mm band (\u223c85\u2013115\u00a0GHz) were obtained with ALMA in order to derive redshifts based on the CO and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] line emission (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). For 18/26 sources, it was possible to derive redshifts based on the identification of two or more emission lines. For 5/26 other sources, only one line was identified, and thus the redshifts were constrained using FIR/submm-based photometric redshifts (see Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). In the remaining 3/26 sources, no lines were identified (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For three other sources, redshifts were identified using spectroscopic observations covering the full 1-mm band (\u223c190\u2013310\u00a0GHz) with the Z-spec instrument on the Atacama Pathfinder Experiment (APEX) 12-m telescope, and confirmed with optical spectroscopy obtained with the Very Large Telescope (VLT). These three sources share the same selection criteria as the ALMA sample of 26 sources (see Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Observations of the CO(1\u22120) emission in two of these three objects, SPT-S\u00a0233227\u22125358.5 and SPT-S\u00a0053816\u22125030.8, were studied in detail in Aravena et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). This makes a total of 18+3=21 SPT sources with confirmed, unambiguous redshifts obtained from millimetre spectroscopy.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Our survey sample is composed of 17 of the 21 SPT sources with redshifts spectroscopically confirmed from ALMA and APEX/Z-spec observations. In these cases, the sources redshifts allowed us to directly target the low-<em>J</em> CO emission lines with the ATCA 7-mm receivers (30\u201350\u00a0GHz). The remaining four sources lie at redshifts where neither low-<em>J</em> CO lines could be observed (<em>z</em> = 2.84\u20133.61). One of these four sources correspond to SPT0551\u221250, which was previously identified at <em>z</em> = 2.1 but has recently been revised as <em>z</em> = 3.1 (Strandet et\u00a0al. in preparation)</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">A wealth of multiwavelength data have been obtained for this sample of galaxies. These include optical spectroscopy of the lens galaxies with the VLT, Gemini and Magellan telescopes and optical/near-infrared imaging with the <em>Hubble Space Telescope</em>; mid-infrared imaging with the <em>Spitzer</em> Infrared Array Camera at 3.6 and 4.5\u00a0\u03bcm; far-infrared imaging with the Photodetector Array Camera and Spectrometer at 100 and 160\u00a0\u03bcm, and with the Spectral and Photometric Imaging Receiver at 250, 350 and 500\u00a0\u03bcm on board of the <em>Herschel</em> space observatory. Millimetre and submillimetre imaging were obtained with the SPT at 3, 2 and 1.4\u00a0mm, and with the Submillimeter APEX Bolometer Camera and the Large Bolometer Camera at 350 and 870\u00a0\u03bcm. For these, independent flux estimates were also obtained with ALMA at 870\u00a0\u03bcm and 3\u00a0mm (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104808 id=\"92104808\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-2>ATCA CO data</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">We used ATCA in its H214 hybrid array configuration to observe either the CO(1\u22120) or the CO(2\u22121) emission line (\u03bd<sub>rest</sub> = 115.2712 and 230.5380\u00a0GHz, respectively) in the galaxies in our sample. We used the ATCA 7-mm receivers, which can be tuned in the frequency range 30\u201350\u00a0GHz. This frequency range covers the redshift ranges 1.38\u20132.84 for CO(1\u22120) and 3.61\u20136.68 for CO(2\u22121). Sources with redshifts in the range <em>z</em> = 2.84\u20133.61 could not be observed in either of these low-<em>J</em> CO lines. The H214 array configuration at these observing frequencies leads to typical beam sizes of 5\u20136\u00a0arcsec, and thus preclude spatially resolving our sources. A summary of our observations is shown in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92104810\" scrollto-destination=\"92104810\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl1\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl1\" data-id=\"tbl1\"><span class=\"label\">Table 1.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Observation summary.</p></div> </div><div class=\"table-overflow\"><table><thead><tr><th>Source<sup><em>a</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th><em>z</em><sup><em>b</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Line<sup><em>c</em></sup><span aria-hidden=\"true\" style=\"display: none;\">\r\n            .\u00a0</span></th><th>Freq. 2-GHz correlator windows, \u03bd<sub>1</sub> and \u03bd<sub>2</sub>. One of them is tuned to observe the low-<em>J</em> CO, the other is used to have an extra measurement of continuum and to target a fainter molecular line.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN005\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN005\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>e</em></sup>Observing dates.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN006\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN006\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>f</em></sup>Phase calibrator used. 53\u00b0\u00a0</td><td>0.45\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J214654\u22125507.8\u00a0</td><td>4.5672\u00a0</td><td>CO(2\u22121)\u00a0</td><td>41.400, 42.400\u00a0</td><td>22, 24, 29-Mar-2013\u00a0</td><td>2204-540\u00a0</td><td>5.4\u2009arcsec \u00d7 4.6\u2009arcsec, 89\u00b0\u00a0</td><td>0.59\u00a0</td></tr><tr><td>J214720\u22125035.9\u00a0</td><td>3.7602\u00a0</td><td>CO(2\u22121)\u00a0</td><td>46.600, 48.400\u00a0</td><td>28, 29, 30-Mar-2013\u00a0</td><td>2204-540\u00a0</td><td>4.6\u2009arcsec \u00d7 3.8\u2009arcsec, 88\u00b0\u00a0</td><td>0.86\u00a0</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class=\"table-wrap-foot\"><span id=\"fn-TFN001\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN001\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Source name.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN002\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN002\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>CO-based redshift obtained through millimetre spectroscopy with ALMA and APEX/Z-spec in the case of SPT0551\u221248.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN003\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN003\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Targeted low-<em>J</em> CO transition.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN004\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN004\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Central observing frequencies for each of the two 2-GHz correlator windows, \u03bd<sub>1</sub> and \u03bd<sub>2</sub>. One of them is tuned to observe the low-<em>J</em> CO, the other is used to have an extra measurement of continuum and to target a fainter molecular line.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN005\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN005\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>e</em></sup>Observing dates.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN006\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN006\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>f</em></sup>Phase calibrator used. In several cases, this coincided with the bandpass calibrator 0537-441.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN007\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN007\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>g</em></sup>Synthesized beam size and position angle.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN008\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN008\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>h</em></sup>rms level achieved at the low-<em>J</em> CO frequency in a channel of 50\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92104810\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The observations were performed as part of projects ID C2744 and C2818 during the periods 2012 October 1\u201310, 2013 March 21\u201331 and 2013 April 1\u20137, and were taken under mostly good weather conditions (atmospheric seeing values 90-400\u2009\u03bcm) with five working antennas.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We used the Compact Array Broadband Backend configured in the wide bandwidth mode (Wilson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib130\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib130\" data-open=\"bib130\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>). This leads to a total bandwidth of 2\u00a0GHz per correlator window and a spectral resolution of 1\u00a0MHz per channel (\u223c6\u201310\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> per channel for the relevant frequency range). In all sources, one of the windows was tuned to observe the CO line, while the other window was tuned to measure the continuum emission or to target another fainter molecular line when possible. Individual tuning frequencies were estimated using the CO-based redshifts from ALMA and APEX/Z-spec spectroscopy (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). The target positions were obtained from the ALMA 3-mm continuum detections (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gain and pointing calibration were performed every 7\u201310\u00a0min and \u223c1\u00a0h, respectively. The gain/pointing calibrators used are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. The bright sources 0537-441 and 1921-293 were used as bandpass calibrators, and Uranus and 1934-638 were used as amplitude calibrators. We expect the flux calibration to be accurate to within 15\u2009per\u2009cent, based on the comparison of the Uranus and 1934-638 fluxes. The software package <span class=\"small-caps\">miriad</span> (Sault, Teuben &amp; Wright <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib102\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib102\" data-open=\"bib102\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>) and the Common Astronomy Software Applications (<span class=\"small-caps\">casa</span>; McMullin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib75\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib75\" data-open=\"bib75\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>) were used for editing, calibration and imaging.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The calibrated visibilities were inverted using the <span class=\"small-caps\">casa</span> task <span class=\"small-caps\">clean</span> using natural weighting and cleaning in a tight box around the source position, down to a threshold of \u223c2.0\u03c3, where \u03c3 is the rms noise level. The final rms and synthesized beam sizes are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl1\" data-open=\"tbl1\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104815 id=\"92104815\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-3>Lensing models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm continuum imaging at 0.5\u00a0arcsec resolution were used to construct gravitational lens models of these objects of all the DSFGs in this study (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). Lens modelling was performed in the measured visibilities, allowing us to account for residual calibration uncertainties inherent in interferometric measurements and avoiding biases introduced by correlated noise when inverting visibilities into the image plane. The procedure used to derive the lens models is similar to the one used by Hezaveh et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). All sources were significantly detected in the ALMA images (SNR &gt;50), providing excellent constraints to these models. Optical and near-infrared spectroscopy of the foreground lenses will be presented in Rotermund et\u00a0al. (in preparation). The derived magnifications are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The ALMA data presented in Spilker et\u00a0al. (in preparation) have much higher spatial resolution (0.5\u00a0arcsec) and sensitivity compared to that presented by Hezaveh et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), which used only the data taken in the compact configuration at a resolution of 1.5\u00a0arcsec. As such, the lens models from Spilker et\u00a0al. are of much better quality. This explains the discrepancy between the magnification for SPT0418\u221247 of \u223c21 derived by Hezaveh et\u00a0al., and the new value of \u223c32 presented in Spilker et\u00a0al. (in preparation, see Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>). Note that in the other two sources with lens models in Hezaveh et\u00a0al. covered here (SPT0346\u221252 and SPT0538\u221250) the derived magnifications are fully consistent.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104818 id=\"92104818\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec2-4>IR data and models</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The far-infrared and (sub-)millimetre data were used to obtain spectral energy distribution (SED) models of the dust emission in the SPT DSFGs (see Greve et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Gullberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The infrared luminosities (<em>L</em><sub>IR</sub>), dust temperatures (<em>T</em><sub>d</sub>) and masses (<em>M</em><sub>d</sub>) used in this study were derived by fitting a single-component modified blackbody dust model to the data (Strandet et\u00a0al. in preparation). We adopt a dust absorption coefficient \u03ba = 0.045 \u00d7 (\u03bd<sub>r</sub>/250GHz)<sup>\u03b2</sup> in units of m<sup>2</sup> kg<sup>\u22121</sup>, with \u03bd<sub>r</sub> the rest-frame frequency in GHz. We use a fixed emissivity index \u03b2 = 2.0, with the opacity equals to unity at \u03bb<sub>0</sub> = 100\u00a0\u03bcm. Following Greve et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib53\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib53\" data-open=\"bib53\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), we fit the data only to \u03bb<sub>rest</sub> &gt; 50\u00a0\u03bcm. Infrared luminosities are obtained by integrating the modelled SED in the range 8\u20131000\u00a0\u03bcm rest frame. Our SPT DSFGs have complete coverage from \u03bb<sub>obs</sub> = 250 to 3000\u00a0\u03bcm (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) allowing us for an accurate determination of the dust properties based on seven photometric data points.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To compare with similar high-redshift galaxy samples, we compiled far-infrared photometry for lensed DSFGs and main-sequence (MS) galaxies with published low-<em>J</em> CO detections (Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Combes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Johansson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Magdis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Magnelli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Rawle et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and derived <em>T</em><sub>d</sub>,\u2009<em>M</em><sub>d</sub> and <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> values using the same procedure as that applied to our SPT sources. These sources were compiled from the various deep extragalactic <em>Herschel</em> surveys, and have accurate and complete photometry from <em>Herschel</em> and other (sub)millimetre facilities (see also Gullberg et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib55\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib55\" data-open=\"bib55\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92104821 id=\"92104821\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec3>RESULTS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The obtained CO spectra are shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1a\" data-open=\"fig1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. Total integrated maps were obtained by collapsing the data cube along the frequency axis in the relevant range containing the detected CO emission line. Total intensities were then computed by spatially fitting a two-dimensional Gaussian to these integrated maps using the task JMFIT from the Astronomical Image Processing System (Greisen <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib50\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib50\" data-open=\"bib50\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1990</a>). Since all sources are unresolved at the achieved resolution, the CO spectra shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1a\" data-open=\"fig1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a> are obtained by measuring the fluxes at the CO peak position of the integrated images. To obtain the CO line central frequency and width, we fit single and double component Gaussian curves to the CO spectrum profiles.</p>                        <a id=\"92104823\" scrollto-destination=\"92104823\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1a\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig1a.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=dRfc8JZG5NuhT27~Sop59Db6bTiAZGv1ZDNt184fccvGK66Io8mVqzxR6zUIez~IIHA7ES9JwXpsToW97r6GjVqrKQHgXLVyYBNQjyDw8WxsIt02dpyoRe40ItrJr80F330rFE7lACOEfwjeqRfvOcLLg9JCNnZLrsCQfQAcLVsRVK1Ec9~Injyxz72nlceWgMjCeYPjim~Veh2e3cjV6t0H0MHLeOr6~tXIkhnxVhurtrbIWcyXoYSy1GvnXReoXOmJEtrZvoJe0ORtjU-rx9yyvywTiuEuN0qynMBwZ~GwZf1DcKDN01yQb3QkT3mPPa8hLS2qFiq0TEuSP0XRTw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"CO (1\u22120/2\u22121) emission line spectra obtained with ATCA in our target SPT SMGs. The reference for <em>v</em> = 0\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in the upper <em>x</em>-axis has been obtained from the inferred ATCA CO redshift.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1a\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig1a.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=dRfc8JZG5NuhT27~Sop59Db6bTiAZGv1ZDNt184fccvGK66Io8mVqzxR6zUIez~IIHA7ES9JwXpsToW97r6GjVqrKQHgXLVyYBNQjyDw8WxsIt02dpyoRe40ItrJr80F330rFE7lACOEfwjeqRfvOcLLg9JCNnZLrsCQfQAcLVsRVK1Ec9~Injyxz72nlceWgMjCeYPjim~Veh2e3cjV6t0H0MHLeOr6~tXIkhnxVhurtrbIWcyXoYSy1GvnXReoXOmJEtrZvoJe0ORtjU-rx9yyvywTiuEuN0qynMBwZ~GwZf1DcKDN01yQb3QkT3mPPa8hLS2qFiq0TEuSP0XRTw__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"CO (1\u22120/2\u22121) emission line spectra obtained with ATCA in our target SPT SMGs. Single or double Gaussian fits are represented by the red lines. The reference for <em>v</em> = 0\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup> in the upper <em>x</em>-axis has been obtained from the inferred ATCA CO redshift.</p></div></div>                        <a id=\"92104824\" scrollto-destination=\"92104824\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig1b\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig1b.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=RSpKFUtvs2PcTfG3Su68B624mFDdKsgVpg46CDTQ-OQvuOmFXIgaBmaZiuzClN1Hs~UnaaJD5PboYnuoFiNE4GLaDFpTBZMstwVkYTdSZpFNqDmCR4NBzZabejA9MqRtUot70xiMOnIBr8L1Q50H0k9erjpeO19JRMZUq0WzOyWygNX~5iE2nC5YhXfPIUbSOBPL6pS3GEpAhOmmwiOLNE1PkIL-XUU-Mw8FR2b6tWHWQzLuS0U-DuuEEByieAi8JcJjrpINWhHvQ7X8koeIGkoHDf0WwGBoHojUU8P2EYq2cKD6i-2RegLt8cjnTGh-v9VkIRW1DybXAD5NDw4mfg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"\u2013 continued.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig1b.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104824/stw275fig1b.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig1b.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104824\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig1b.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=IxTR0GaLzZQooQ7hx7okt2CFPxKTbIG-AhH~I7dTxW6Cc0S6jDIELhpLwtzt10ZAdSyYUOLeaxpM4Vpt3Y5NkuSqvF3gMb8LWxdKr4OaZqdVTjiCB4f8~Xt8sPvCicjwwhzCKF~NnR-6WVvm7bQvYXhRhD7Gvgq2Vxp~z3FTIerfXPZJPtxLpps-oiuqj5Fk6BeINe2KduZkj-kYQtAj1-8H0ixLcx532-U90IUC4oeOrclAmKRbQUPENXtuO3p5yrFHbNigYoVZWVKtrzB58PvztGqf31Qkf4E7RYeuzGMpEI7KpfuCYAu2upRSLteYfC05VwgnNQdPggp9Gn~3Wg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104824&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig1b.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2013 <em>continued</em>.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig1b\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 1</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig1b.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=RSpKFUtvs2PcTfG3Su68B624mFDdKsgVpg46CDTQ-OQvuOmFXIgaBmaZiuzClN1Hs~UnaaJD5PboYnuoFiNE4GLaDFpTBZMstwVkYTdSZpFNqDmCR4NBzZabejA9MqRtUot70xiMOnIBr8L1Q50H0k9erjpeO19JRMZUq0WzOyWygNX~5iE2nC5YhXfPIUbSOBPL6pS3GEpAhOmmwiOLNE1PkIL-XUU-Mw8FR2b6tWHWQzLuS0U-DuuEEByieAi8JcJjrpINWhHvQ7X8koeIGkoHDf0WwGBoHojUU8P2EYq2cKD6i-2RegLt8cjnTGh-v9VkIRW1DybXAD5NDw4mfg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"\u2013 continued.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig1b.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104824/stw275fig1b.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig1b.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104824\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig1b.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=IxTR0GaLzZQooQ7hx7okt2CFPxKTbIG-AhH~I7dTxW6Cc0S6jDIELhpLwtzt10ZAdSyYUOLeaxpM4Vpt3Y5NkuSqvF3gMb8LWxdKr4OaZqdVTjiCB4f8~Xt8sPvCicjwwhzCKF~NnR-6WVvm7bQvYXhRhD7Gvgq2Vxp~z3FTIerfXPZJPtxLpps-oiuqj5Fk6BeINe2KduZkj-kYQtAj1-8H0ixLcx532-U90IUC4oeOrclAmKRbQUPENXtuO3p5yrFHbNigYoVZWVKtrzB58PvztGqf31Qkf4E7RYeuzGMpEI7KpfuCYAu2upRSLteYfC05VwgnNQdPggp9Gn~3Wg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104824&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig1b.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u2013 <em>continued</em>.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The CO spectra of most sources are consistent with single-peaked Gaussian profiles. However, there are two sources where the profile and significance of the detection is consistent with double-peaked profiles, SPT0113\u221246 and SPT2103\u221260. Two other sources, SPT0452\u221250 and SPT0441\u221246, also show tentative signs of double-peaked CO profiles, but the evidence for multiple components is small at the depth of these data.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The spectrum of SPT2134\u221250 is shown averaged over broader channels in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig1a\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig1a\" data-open=\"fig1a\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">1</a>. In this case, the significance of the detection is \u223c5\u03c3. The CO(1\u22120) line profile was checked against that measured in the CO(3\u22122) line from the ALMA 3-mm spectroscopy (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib128\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib128\" data-open=\"bib128\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>); we confirm that the linewidth and strength of the lines are consistent. In particular, the ratio between both CO lines, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$R_{31}=L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO 3-2}/L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO 1-0}\\sim 1$|</span> is comparable to that observed in other star-forming galaxies at high redshift (e.g. Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">We computed CO luminosities in units of K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup> using equation 3 from Solomon et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>). Note that <em>L</em>\u2032 line luminosities are related to <em>L</em> luminosities, in units of <em>L</em><sub>\u2299</sub>, by <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L/L^{\\prime } = (8\\pi k_{\\rm B}/c^2) \\nu _{\\rm rest}^3$|\u2060</span>, where <em>k</em><sub>B</sub> is the Boltzmann constant, <em>c</em> is the speed of light and \u03bd<sub>rest</sub> is the line rest-frame frequency. For the CO(1\u22120) line, this yields <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{\\rm CO}/L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}=4.9\\times 10^{-5}$|\u2060</span>, with <em>L</em><sub>CO</sub> in units of <em>L</em><sub>\u2299</sub>. For sources that have been detected in the <em>J</em> = 2 \u2212 1 transition, we convert to the ground level by assuming a line brightness temperature ratio between the CO(2\u22121) and CO(1\u22120) lines of 0.9. This ratio is consistent with previous findings for DSFGs where an average ratio of 0.85 was found for a sample of 32 sources (Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), consistent within the uncertainties with the line ratio of \u223c0.7 found for star-forming disc galaxies at <em>z</em> = 1.5\u20132.0 (Aravena et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib3\" data-open=\"bib3\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib6\" data-open=\"bib6\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), and follows the average ratio of \u223c1.1 found through stacking of the SPT DSFGs themselves (Spilker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib110\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib110\" data-open=\"bib110\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). The measured intensities, luminosities, linewidths and frequencies are given in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92104828\" scrollto-destination=\"92104828\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl2\" content-id=\"TFN009\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Redshift from the low-<em>J</em> CO lines.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN010\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN010\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>CO line full width half-maximum (FWHM) velocity.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN011\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN011\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Integrated CO line intensity (<em>I</em><sub>CO</sub> = \u222b<em>S</em><sub>CO</sub>d<em>v</em>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN012\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN012\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Observed CO line luminosity in units of <em>l</em><sub>0</sub> = (\u00d7 10<sup>11</sup> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN013\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN013\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>e</em></sup>Continuum flux at the observed frequency \u03bd<sub>cont</sub>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN014\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN014\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>f</em></sup>Velocity difference between the two line peaks is given instead of CO FWHM.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN015\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN015\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>g</em></sup>Observed properties taken from Aravena et\u00a0al.
