content-id=\"TFN009\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Redshift from the low-<em>J</em> CO lines.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN010\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN010\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>CO line full width half-maximum (FWHM) velocity.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN011\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN011\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>Integrated CO line intensity (<em>I</em><sub>CO</sub> = \u222b<em>S</em><sub>CO</sub>d<em>v</em>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN012\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN012\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Observed CO line luminosity in units of <em>l</em><sub>0</sub> = (\u00d7 10<sup>11</sup> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN013\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN013\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>e</em></sup>Continuum flux at the observed frequency \u03bd<sub>cont</sub>.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN014\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN014\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>f</em></sup>Velocity difference between the two line peaks is given instead of CO FWHM.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN015\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN015\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>g</em></sup>Observed properties taken from Aravena et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib5\" data-open=\"bib5\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92104828\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Measurements of the continuum emission were obtained by collapsing the data along the frequency axis in the line-free SPW and channels around the line. Flux measurements were obtained by fitting a two-dimensional Gaussian to the resulting continuum map. The derived continuum fluxes are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl2\" data-open=\"tbl2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92104830 id=\"92104830\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4>ANALYSIS</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104831 id=\"92104831\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-1>Linewidths</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Previous studies have found a wide range of CO full width at half-maximum (FWHM) linewidths for DSFGs (Neri et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib83\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib83\" data-open=\"bib83\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>; Greve et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib52\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib52\" data-open=\"bib52\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>; Tacconi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib114\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib114\" data-open=\"bib114\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>). The mean value for CO FWHM found by Bothwell et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) in the largest sample of (unlensed) DSFGs studied to date is 510 \u00b1 80\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Individual values range from 200\u20131400\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Even though this study used mostly <em>J</em> &gt; 2 transitions of CO, a subsample of these galaxies were detected in <em>J</em> = 2. For these sources, the mean CO FWHM is consistent with the full sample within the statistical uncertainties.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For a more straightforward comparison, in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a> we show the cumulative distribution of CO FWHM for different samples of galaxies that have been detected in low-<em>J</em> CO (<em>J</em> \u2264 2), including the comparison sample of lensed DSFGs described in Section 2.3 (Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Combes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Johansson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Rawle et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib92\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib92\" data-open=\"bib92\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), a compilation of 23 unlensed DSFGs from the literature (Coppin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Carilli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib94\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib94\" data-open=\"bib94\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011a</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">c</a>; Thomson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and a sample of 13 MS galaxies at <em>z</em> = 1.0\u20131.5 (Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Magnelli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"92104834\" scrollto-destination=\"92104834\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=2l5nkUxki59OzY7PXyoQutBNj2DEJVtIIgwxXr4d9E3AvR-Z00wj3izMXpq4Og-Tty4TeS8Gxz2DZPvwO6HwQvhZGVil-frUeUyjgZ1YPGuRvW7-t5oltgPPHLKXGS-r0hnnsUXpLbGQGjRIwFTL8cPRW~XB9VlMXhP1~1k5OyD5dKXxvnzKySkkDQfdhxAH5NF8epoD9JoHlcLgDR8WElXjdOHmwoJFZYESlFoD0vUL2LVsuAI5TdN8IVCk4GiUdog1ddPYe~aizF5oEAQYXo8x4JXhJTkKAY9ENxbDvms1tb2GluQOrtAjh7~uIDelzCLyxvfiysShJoFe1-v0wA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative distribution of linewidths (FWHM) derived from the CO profiles for the SPT DSFGs, shown as a black solid histogram, compared with the cumulative distribution of linewidths for other high-redshift galaxy samples with available J \u2264 2 CO measurements. The orange dashed histogram shows the distribution for the lensed DSFGs from literature (see text). The blue dotted histogram shows a literature compilation of unlensed DSFGs and the green dot\u2013dashed histogram represents a sample of MS star-forming galaxies at z = 1\u20132.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104834/stw275fig2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104834\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=I4LGx4M6gjVlA1Z3-4z0yirHgGrbwZZHmoSiS06cjIV2qQLd9GvedNWTpXUcMmYX~-Y3k75BeISgaB2Jirc-I1WX6sn3QaEVuZSnFj7ocnDKHGjBFWJTNVGLPc5YkSsaax3KOL8fSttNK8yM91TPw0bWqEsmZKNR1QYphnu3tGBwQnYCkAMlewYxi0iHcErvNl1Icm-4GuvurPidqiXkbgjUIjEDmk9GcaaPy8XWqjj9PADdGL4TG2kJSt4L~hNSgeSfTes9LtowrtcCzge53ocyNgRC64uPKKttkbkQcogZ1OX5bpryBdYRvzew7z8n3V544iB0bTjt~CLFd0O-2A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104834&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative distribution of linewidths (FWHM) derived from the CO profiles for the SPT DSFGs, shown as a black solid histogram, compared with the cumulative distribution of linewidths for other high-redshift galaxy samples with available <em>J</em> \u2264 2 CO measurements. The orange dashed histogram shows the distribution for the lensed DSFGs from literature (see text). The blue dotted histogram shows a literature compilation of unlensed DSFGs and the green dot\u2013dashed histogram represents a sample of MS star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> = 1\u20132.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig2\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 2.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=2l5nkUxki59OzY7PXyoQutBNj2DEJVtIIgwxXr4d9E3AvR-Z00wj3izMXpq4Og-Tty4TeS8Gxz2DZPvwO6HwQvhZGVil-frUeUyjgZ1YPGuRvW7-t5oltgPPHLKXGS-r0hnnsUXpLbGQGjRIwFTL8cPRW~XB9VlMXhP1~1k5OyD5dKXxvnzKySkkDQfdhxAH5NF8epoD9JoHlcLgDR8WElXjdOHmwoJFZYESlFoD0vUL2LVsuAI5TdN8IVCk4GiUdog1ddPYe~aizF5oEAQYXo8x4JXhJTkKAY9ENxbDvms1tb2GluQOrtAjh7~uIDelzCLyxvfiysShJoFe1-v0wA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Cumulative distribution of linewidths (FWHM) derived from the CO profiles for the SPT DSFGs, shown as a black solid histogram, compared with the cumulative distribution of linewidths for other high-redshift galaxy samples with available J \u2264 2 CO measurements. The orange dashed histogram shows the distribution for the lensed DSFGs from literature (see text). The blue dotted histogram shows a literature compilation of unlensed DSFGs and the green dot\u2013dashed histogram represents a sample of MS star-forming galaxies at z = 1\u20132.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig2.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104834/stw275fig2.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig2.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104834\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig2.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=I4LGx4M6gjVlA1Z3-4z0yirHgGrbwZZHmoSiS06cjIV2qQLd9GvedNWTpXUcMmYX~-Y3k75BeISgaB2Jirc-I1WX6sn3QaEVuZSnFj7ocnDKHGjBFWJTNVGLPc5YkSsaax3KOL8fSttNK8yM91TPw0bWqEsmZKNR1QYphnu3tGBwQnYCkAMlewYxi0iHcErvNl1Icm-4GuvurPidqiXkbgjUIjEDmk9GcaaPy8XWqjj9PADdGL4TG2kJSt4L~hNSgeSfTes9LtowrtcCzge53ocyNgRC64uPKKttkbkQcogZ1OX5bpryBdYRvzew7z8n3V544iB0bTjt~CLFd0O-2A__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104834&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig2.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Cumulative distribution of linewidths (FWHM) derived from the CO profiles for the SPT DSFGs, shown as a black solid histogram, compared with the cumulative distribution of linewidths for other high-redshift galaxy samples with available <em>J</em> \u2264 2 CO measurements. The orange dashed histogram shows the distribution for the lensed DSFGs from literature (see text). The blue dotted histogram shows a literature compilation of unlensed DSFGs and the green dot\u2013dashed histogram represents a sample of MS star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> = 1\u20132.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Qualitatively, the distributions of all samples appear to be different, particularly when comparing with the unlensed DSFG sample. SPT DSFGs have a distribution concentrated at smaller linewidths, whereas most of the unlensed DSFGs from the literature show larger linewidths. Literature lensed DSFGs appear to follow the distribution of SPT DSFGs at linewidths &lt;400\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, but then they depart to large linewidths. The SPT DSFGs show a weighted-average FWHM of 370 \u00b1 130\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, where the uncertainty includes the scatter in the sample. This compares well with the literature lensed DSFGs, which show a weighted-average FWHM of 320 \u00b1 290\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>, and is also compatible with the average for MS galaxies at <em>z</em> &lt; 2 of 320 \u00b1 160\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. Unlensed DSFGs, however, show a larger average linewidth of 470 \u00b1 220\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>. This difference is obvious from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig2\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig2\" data-open=\"fig2\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">2</a>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To quantify the difference between the linewidth distribution of the various samples, we performed a Kolmogorov\u2013Smirnov (KS) test. We measure the KS probability <em>P</em> that a pair of data sets are drawn from the same distribution. Low values of <em>P</em> indicate that both data sets are significantly different. We compared the FWHM distribution of the SPT DSFG sample with the literature lensed DSFGs, the MS galaxies and the unlensed DSFGs, and found <em>P</em>\u00a0=\u00a00.86, 0.60 and 0.25, respectively. Such values indicate that the linewidth distribution of the SPT DSFGs is compatible with that of other galaxy populations, in particular, with literature lensed DSFGs (as expected) and MS galaxies. Furthermore, with <em>P</em> = 0.25, there is suggestive evidence that the SPT and unlensed DSFG samples do not come from the same linewidth distribution.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104837 id=\"92104837\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-2><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> versus FWHM</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on physical arguments about the ability of the CO line emission to trace mass and kinematics, Bothwell et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) suggested an empirical relationship between the CO luminosity (<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">\u2060|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|\u2060</span>) and the CO linewidth at FWHM (\u0394<em>v</em><sub>FWHM</sub>), with the form <em>L</em>\u2032 = <em>a</em>(\u0394<em>v</em><sub>FWHM</sub>)<sup><em>b</em></sup>, where <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are parameters to be obtained from observational data.</p><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Under the premise that this relationship holds for gravitationally lensed sources, Harris et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) suggested the use of this relationship to obtain a measurement of the magnification \u03bc, assuming the intrinsic (true) luminosity is related to the observed luminosity by <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ1\" content-id=\"equ1\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nL^{\\prime }_{\\rm obs}=\\mu L^{\\prime }_{\\rm intrinsic}=\\mu a (\\Delta v_{\\rm FWHM})^b.\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(1)</span></div>Therefore, <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu =L^{\\prime }_{\\rm obs}/a(\\Delta v_{\\rm FWHM})^b$|</span> can be derived from CO measurements.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we test the method to obtain lens magnifications from CO, by comparing the true magnification obtained from lens modelling of the dust emission, \u03bc<sub>870\u2009\u03bcm</sub>, for lensed DSFGs with the magnification factors inferred from the CO linewidth\u2013<em>L</em>\u2032 relation, \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> shows the relationship between <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> and the line FWHM that is obtained for unlensed DSFGs and MS galaxies that have low-<em>J</em> CO detections (Frayer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Coppin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Carilli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Thomson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). We specifically consider only sources with low-<em>J</em> CO measurements (CO 1\u22120 or CO 2\u22121) to avoid uncertainties from different line transitions having different linewidths. The solid line shows a best-fitting relationship to unlensed DSFGs and MS galaxies at <em>z</em> = 1\u20132. The dashed line shows the best-fitting relationship presented in equation <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ2\"></span><a href=\"#equ2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> of Harris et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), which includes unlensed DSFGs but not MS galaxies. Due to the significant scatter in individual CO luminosities that can span nearby an order of magnitude and uncertainties in linewidths, both relationships provide a similar fit to the data points.</p>                        <a id=\"92104842\" scrollto-destination=\"92104842\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=sOZg-QxuOAj~Y8XIvIB0BEH0mTgPfWtt-3H-i3CX-UaFvRv2RYp52EFrKRrBwVw4SBohR1592AtLptpZ0co2PRSoECpkRizeKcvuWVe5EcJjIyExd-e~1G-aNP~hU0AVKGRx4LXe510fNvXufEO~MZ7N7ul5imy1g3I15fXANgHs0EE1Vj9MjPg04vnbD26i6Akd4jb2edMbs4ZwqQAqKJXIrYmBZMJTYtCOfSrcCrOZiIH73N-2jckGYKazFucupUVgrEG-aryH0nSbKFJVSn5vVY5vbeMW7tZN-H4x9ZW5yaozJsEBTae813q66qgddVGYdp7D4TrqyTjcO6fdWQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$ versus FWHM for our SPT DSFGs (black filled circles), compared to a literature compilation of lensed DSFGS (orange squares) and unlensed DSFGs (grey squares). The solid line shows the best-fitting relation obtained for unlensed DSFGs, which include in this case both SMGs and MS galaxies. The dashed line shows the best-fitting relation found by Harris et\u00a0al. (2012) for unlensed DSFGs. The dotted lines show a simple \u2018virial\u2019 functional form for the CO luminosity for a compact starburst and an extended disc (see text).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104842/stw275fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104842\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=jkZQWQxeSaNUtkFHK6T9aRRJRr1HwQIJDyfR8cLj~OPSZVA2l-NtRp5mUfaoUbY8cMW8flwF8nhk25wzFEra8jFt9RTzZkyjb4t5jYNUOGOe~yBO0x6n32kqjL1Rz46GBu0rb2qb838aBBs5t9DkbJxKF24gnQ-cPQ9kD4N4bf7T9X-c0MmQmGt-HSgdbLswHtt~4VmiIBw~q9hexJ2wZ4MQiH~zT~ocn1gqx-t012s9E2Ovam-CPJPWDG~lsMSGffRhY9mZHOflmHI6s6B4sJw2DLSvcwEyiafIhrNVCm4fETK07EdlYitnM7ng41N1MOKW0jkFCRK0pykWHNDAow__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104842&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> versus FWHM for our SPT DSFGs (black filled circles), compared to a literature compilation of lensed DSFGS (orange squares) and unlensed DSFGs (grey squares). The solid line shows the best-fitting relation obtained for unlensed DSFGs, which include in this case both SMGs and MS galaxies. The dashed line shows the best-fitting relation found by Harris et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) for unlensed DSFGs. The dotted lines show a simple \u2018virial\u2019 functional form for the CO luminosity for a compact starburst and an extended disc (see text).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig3\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 3.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=sOZg-QxuOAj~Y8XIvIB0BEH0mTgPfWtt-3H-i3CX-UaFvRv2RYp52EFrKRrBwVw4SBohR1592AtLptpZ0co2PRSoECpkRizeKcvuWVe5EcJjIyExd-e~1G-aNP~hU0AVKGRx4LXe510fNvXufEO~MZ7N7ul5imy1g3I15fXANgHs0EE1Vj9MjPg04vnbD26i6Akd4jb2edMbs4ZwqQAqKJXIrYmBZMJTYtCOfSrcCrOZiIH73N-2jckGYKazFucupUVgrEG-aryH0nSbKFJVSn5vVY5vbeMW7tZN-H4x9ZW5yaozJsEBTae813q66qgddVGYdp7D4TrqyTjcO6fdWQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$ versus FWHM for our SPT DSFGs (black filled circles), compared to a literature compilation of lensed DSFGS (orange squares) and unlensed DSFGs (grey squares). The solid line shows the best-fitting relation obtained for unlensed DSFGs, which include in this case both SMGs and MS galaxies. The dashed line shows the best-fitting relation found by Harris et\u00a0al. (2012) for unlensed DSFGs. The dotted lines show a simple \u2018virial\u2019 functional form for the CO luminosity for a compact starburst and an extended disc (see text).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig3.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104842/stw275fig3.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig3.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104842\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig3.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=jkZQWQxeSaNUtkFHK6T9aRRJRr1HwQIJDyfR8cLj~OPSZVA2l-NtRp5mUfaoUbY8cMW8flwF8nhk25wzFEra8jFt9RTzZkyjb4t5jYNUOGOe~yBO0x6n32kqjL1Rz46GBu0rb2qb838aBBs5t9DkbJxKF24gnQ-cPQ9kD4N4bf7T9X-c0MmQmGt-HSgdbLswHtt~4VmiIBw~q9hexJ2wZ4MQiH~zT~ocn1gqx-t012s9E2Ovam-CPJPWDG~lsMSGffRhY9mZHOflmHI6s6B4sJw2DLSvcwEyiafIhrNVCm4fETK07EdlYitnM7ng41N1MOKW0jkFCRK0pykWHNDAow__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104842&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig3.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> versus FWHM for our SPT DSFGs (black filled circles), compared to a literature compilation of lensed DSFGS (orange squares) and unlensed DSFGs (grey squares). The solid line shows the best-fitting relation obtained for unlensed DSFGs, which include in this case both SMGs and MS galaxies. The dashed line shows the best-fitting relation found by Harris et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>) for unlensed DSFGs. The dotted lines show a simple \u2018virial\u2019 functional form for the CO luminosity for a compact starburst and an extended disc (see text).</p></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;            block-child-p&#xA;            \">Following Bothwell et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), we also show a simple parametrization for <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|\u2060</span>: <div class=\"formula-wrap\"><div class=\"disp-formula\" id=\"equ2\" content-id=\"equ2\"><div class=\"tex-math display-math\"> \\begin{equation}\r\nL^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO} = C \\left(\\frac{\\Delta v_{\\rm FWHM}}{2.35}\\right)^2 \\frac{R}{\\alpha _{\\rm CO} G},\r\n\\end{equation} </div></div><span class=\"label\">(2)</span></div>where \u0394<em>v</em><sub>FWHM</sub> is the CO linewidth at FWHM in km s<sup>\u22121</sup>, <em>R</em> is the radius of the CO emitting region in parsecs, <em>G</em> is the gravitational constant, \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> is the CO luminosity to gas mass conversion factor in units of K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup> and <em>C</em> is a constant that accounts for the geometry of the galaxy (Erb et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib43\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib43\" data-open=\"bib43\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2006</a>; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>, we overlay two cases that bracket the range of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> for a given line FWHM: a disc galaxy model for which <em>C</em> = 2.1, <em>R</em> = 5\u00a0kpc, \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 4.6; and a virialized spherical source geometry with <em>C</em> = 5, <em>R</em> = 2\u00a0kpc, \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 1.0.</div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Also shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> are the CO measurements obtained for the SPT DSFGs and a compilation of gravitationally lensed DSFGs with low-<em>J</em> CO measurements (Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Lestrade et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The most notable feature is the relatively flat distribution of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> values with varying linewidths. This flat distribution suggests that galaxies with narrower linewidths need larger magnification corrections.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">To obtain the magnification factor, one only needs to correct by the difference between the observed CO luminosity, and the unlensed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}\\text{-}$|</span> FWHM relation for a given \u0394<em>v</em><sub>FWHM</sub>. We used our best-fitting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}\\text{-}$|</span>FWHM relationship from Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> to compute a CO-based magnification estimate \u03bc<sub>CO</sub> for the SPT DSFGs. The derived values are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                        <a id=\"92104846\" scrollto-destination=\"92104846\"></a>\r\n<div content-id=\"tbl3\" class=\"table-modal table-full-width-wrap\"><div class=\"table-wrap table-wide\"><div class=\"table-wrap-title\" id=\"tbl3\" data-id=\"tbl3\"><span class=\"label\">Table 3.</span><div class=\"caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Derived physical properties.</p></div> id=\"fn-TFN016\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN016\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Source name.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN017\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN017\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Magnification factor obtained through visibility-based lens modelling of ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm continuum imaging data at 0.5\u00a0arcsec resolution (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN018\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN018\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>CO-derived magnification factor, computed using the following relation: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu _{\\rm CO}=3\\times (L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}/10^{11})(\\Delta v_{\\rm FWHM}/400)^{-2.3}$|\u2060</span>, where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> is the measured CO luminosity in units of (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>) and \u0394<em>v</em><sub>FWHM</sub> is the measured linewidth at FWHM in km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. See Section 4.2.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN019\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN019\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Dust properties derived from multiwavelength SED fitting. The parameters listed here have not been corrected for lensing magnification.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN020\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN020\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>e</em></sup>Gas mass derived from the observed CO luminosity assuming \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8, and divided by the lensing magnification \u03bc where available. A typical value of \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a010\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05 was used when a lensing model was not available, for SPT0551\u221248 and SPT2332\u221253.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN021\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN021\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>f</em></sup>Dynamical mass estimated from the line FWHM and the lensing derived effective radius (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation), and assuming a virialized spherical geometry as described in the text. No estimate is provided for SPT0125\u221247 given the complex source geometry seen in the source\u2013plane ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm image.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN022\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN022\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>g</em></sup>Dust-derived CO luminosity to gas mass conversion factor, in units \u03b1<sub>0</sub> = M<sub>\u2299</sub> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN023\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN023\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>h</em></sup>Limit to the CO luminosity to gas mass conversion factor based on a maximum dynamical mass.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow id=\"fn-TFN016\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN016\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>Notes.</em><sup><em>a</em></sup>Source name.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN017\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN017\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>b</em></sup>Magnification factor obtained through visibility-based lens modelling of ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm continuum imaging data at 0.5\u00a0arcsec resolution (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation; Hezaveh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib58\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib58\" data-open=\"bib58\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN018\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN018\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>c</em></sup>CO-derived magnification factor, computed using the following relation: <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\mu _{\\rm CO}=3\\times (L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}/10^{11})(\\Delta v_{\\rm FWHM}/400)^{-2.3}$|\u2060</span>, where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> is the measured CO luminosity in units of (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>) and \u0394<em>v</em><sub>FWHM</sub> is the measured linewidth at FWHM in km s<sup>\u22121</sup>. See Section 4.2.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN019\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN019\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>d</em></sup>Dust properties derived from multiwavelength SED fitting. The parameters listed here have not been corrected for lensing magnification.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN020\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN020\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>e</em></sup>Gas mass derived from the observed CO luminosity assuming \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8, and divided by the lensing magnification \u03bc where available. A typical value of \u03bc\u00a0=\u00a010\u00a0\u00b1\u00a05 was used when a lensing model was not available, for SPT0551\u221248 and SPT2332\u221253.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN021\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN021\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>f</em></sup>Dynamical mass estimated from the line FWHM and the lensing derived effective radius (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation), and assuming a virialized spherical geometry as described in the text. No estimate is provided for SPT0125\u221247 given the complex source geometry seen in the source\u2013plane ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm image.</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN022\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN022\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>g</em></sup>Dust-derived CO luminosity to gas mass conversion factor, in units \u03b1<sub>0</sub> = M<sub>\u2299</sub> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>).</p></span></div><span id=\"fn-TFN023\"></span><div content-id=\"TFN023\"><span class=\"fn\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><sup><em>h</em></sup>Limit to the CO luminosity to gas mass conversion factor based on a maximum dynamical mass.</p></span></div></div><div class=\"&#xA;          graphic-wrap&#xA;          \"><a class=\"fig-view-orig openInAnotherWindow btn js-view-large\" target=\"_blank\" href=\"/view-large/92104846\">\r\n          Open in new tab\r\n        </a></div></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig4\" data-open=\"fig4\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">4</a> we quantify the accuracy of the \u03bc<sub>CO</sub> values, by comparing them to the magnification values obtained through lens modelling of the dust continuum emission \u03bc<sub>d</sub> where available (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation).</p>                        <a id=\"92104848\" scrollto-destination=\"92104848\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=RvXvl5xIwydIllZZCp7n7iL0-U8GJLZ68GqpUWRiFeSMh28UTSYp5V628xGAVBOxwFwhMIfu5noL9p~umvHD5L2Gm~WvlBAacwyv-BihlNKHfDYT4ciGOiLCwhqu~mXLKfZ~z66K~vl6Xn67k-xH83-Ye8UL04Bu9RgK28s9TlANRLV30WjDTlImNdJSIUoBOHFDGoTJZ5JuI3uGAgh3cSqfdz~hxgP6WMljsj4bm3Z-U4o8aoa9NS3BCvH9d~CoKu7i-aA3vGHuMqruB26kU6jylSccaVcOesCsG5~h0WU1GHr7rGiZ3zggKZ6aSXaA-dbLOLwZe2sDBQGNo5H1DQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Lensing magnification factors obtained by assuming the best-fitting $L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$ versus FWHM line, \u03bcCO, compared to the actual magnification obtained from lens modelling for SPT DSFGs (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). Also shown are lensed DSFGs from the literature for which a value of \u03bc was available (Fu et\u00a0al. 2012; Johansson et\u00a0al. 2012; Bussmann et\u00a0al. 2013; Riechers et\u00a0al. 2013). Left: \u03bc versus \u03bcCO. Right: fractional difference between \u03bc and \u03bcCO. The dashed line represents the case where \u03bcCO = \u03bc. The dotted lines enclose cases where there is an agreement between both estimates of &lt;50\u2009per\u2009cent.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104848/stw275fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104848\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=2PuhkgD3ICaxweFnI7eZ87A8xT5ZYNI0GcdoBupy-8Vg78JC1HF5JtkDuOlQ8y~hJddnVGvmAXLBhXE1ehCB6qT75DdYhKTJeuOkGUfMBlRwXq5HMzPvFveZziVQVEwYEU9FJuYEO2Ena-eqRWjdqoOUlUuiGoJpI8IhR5w~32drbeZFrj60NaWvn5-37q-EmHo~vsANEuYiRof-si4YvnO3aE2KJIzSzLTh8iYQBxU3jdKgnuf6IF~deHRPNzOmJin8PR0RmC8wslQoJhrm857PcMPIN4CaAHOXGZuvQr9uq418qt7n19M9MzmualxTSvmiOIDmPpjTAa3VfOykzg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104848&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing magnification factors obtained by assuming the best-fitting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> versus FWHM line, \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>, compared to the actual magnification obtained from lens modelling for SPT DSFGs (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). Also shown are lensed DSFGs from the literature for which a value of \u03bc was available (Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Johansson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Left: \u03bc versus \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>. Right: fractional difference between \u03bc and \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>. The dashed line represents the case where \u03bc<sub>CO</sub> = \u03bc. The dotted lines enclose cases where there is an agreement between both estimates of &lt;50\u2009per\u2009cent.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=RvXvl5xIwydIllZZCp7n7iL0-U8GJLZ68GqpUWRiFeSMh28UTSYp5V628xGAVBOxwFwhMIfu5noL9p~umvHD5L2Gm~WvlBAacwyv-BihlNKHfDYT4ciGOiLCwhqu~mXLKfZ~z66K~vl6Xn67k-xH83-Ye8UL04Bu9RgK28s9TlANRLV30WjDTlImNdJSIUoBOHFDGoTJZ5JuI3uGAgh3cSqfdz~hxgP6WMljsj4bm3Z-U4o8aoa9NS3BCvH9d~CoKu7i-aA3vGHuMqruB26kU6jylSccaVcOesCsG5~h0WU1GHr7rGiZ3zggKZ6aSXaA-dbLOLwZe2sDBQGNo5H1DQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Lensing magnification factors obtained by assuming the best-fitting $L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$ versus FWHM line, \u03bcCO, compared to the actual magnification obtained from lens modelling for SPT DSFGs (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). Also shown are lensed DSFGs from the literature for which a value of \u03bc was available (Fu et\u00a0al. 2012; Johansson et\u00a0al. 2012; Bussmann et\u00a0al. 2013; Riechers et\u00a0al. 2013). Left: \u03bc versus \u03bcCO. Right: fractional difference between \u03bc and \u03bcCO. The dashed line represents the case where \u03bcCO = \u03bc. The dotted lines enclose cases where there is an agreement between both estimates of &lt;50\u2009per\u2009cent.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104848/stw275fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104848\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=2PuhkgD3ICaxweFnI7eZ87A8xT5ZYNI0GcdoBupy-8Vg78JC1HF5JtkDuOlQ8y~hJddnVGvmAXLBhXE1ehCB6qT75DdYhKTJeuOkGUfMBlRwXq5HMzPvFveZziVQVEwYEU9FJuYEO2Ena-eqRWjdqoOUlUuiGoJpI8IhR5w~32drbeZFrj60NaWvn5-37q-EmHo~vsANEuYiRof-si4YvnO3aE2KJIzSzLTh8iYQBxU3jdKgnuf6IF~deHRPNzOmJin8PR0RmC8wslQoJhrm857PcMPIN4CaAHOXGZuvQr9uq418qt7n19M9MzmualxTSvmiOIDmPpjTAa3VfOykzg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104848&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing magnification factors obtained by assuming the best-fitting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> versus FWHM line, \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>, compared to the actual magnification obtained from lens modelling for SPT DSFGs (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). Also shown are lensed DSFGs from the literature for which a value of \u03bc was available (Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Johansson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Left: \u03bc versus \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>. Right: fractional difference between \u03bc and \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>. The dashed line represents the case where \u03bc<sub>CO</sub> = \u03bc. The dotted lines enclose cases where there is an agreement between both estimates of &lt;50\u2009per\u2009cent.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The large scatter in the unlensed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}\\text{-}$|</span>FWHM relationship shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> (about an order of magnitude) makes it highly unreliable to derive accurate magnification factors from CO measurements. For only nine out of the 28 objects with available \u03bc<sub>d</sub> values (32\u2009per\u2009cent of the sample), the difference amounts to \u2272 50\u2009per\u2009cent (i.e. \u0394\u03bc/\u03bc &lt; 0.5 or 0.5\u2009\u03bc<sub>d</sub> &lt; \u03bc<sub>CO</sub> &lt; 1.5\u2009\u03bc<sub>d</sub>). This means that most sources have CO-derived magnification values that significantly differ from the values obtained from lens modelling. Interestingly, for several of the sources with \u03bc<sub>d</sub> &lt; 8 the CO-based estimate severely overpredicts the magnification (\u0394\u03bc/\u03bc &gt; 1). Even if we remove the outlier objects (with \u0394\u03bc/\u03bc &gt; 1), there will be 11 objects with \u0394\u03bc/\u03bc &gt; 0.5 and only nine objects with \u0394\u03bc/\u03bc &lt; 0.5.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The reason why the outlier sources show significant deviations with respect to \u03bc<sub>d</sub> value is not clear, and there is no clear trend among the CO observables (e.g. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|\u2060</span>, FWHM, signal to noise ratio) that could hint for an effective prior selection of outliers. We suggest two possible explanations for this exceedingly large discrepancies on the derived magnification factor: (1) inaccurate lensing models; and (2) unsampled parameter space in the <em>L</em><sub>CO</sub> versus FWHM plane for both lensed and unlensed sources.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">First, this discrepancy might be related to inaccurate lensing models. Four of the sources with the larger \u03bc deviations, which belong to the sample of Harris et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), do have somewhat peculiar lens configurations as shown by recent high-resolution submillimetre 880\u00a0\u03bcm imaging (Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). More specifically (see Bussmann et\u00a0al. for details): J090302.9\u2212014127 presents one of the most compact lens image separations of their sample, and it is possible that the lens itself contributes to the submillimetre emission; J091305.0\u2212005343 corresponds to the largest background source in their sample; In J133649.9+291801, the optical images do not show a lens source, even though the submillimetre map shows evidence for strong lensing; and J141351.9\u2212000026 shows no counter image in the submillimetre map being thus possibly not strongly lensed. Similarly, SPT2132\u221258 appears to be a compact source in the ALMA images and lens models (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). Hence, it is possible that the largest differences between the lens-model and CO-based magnification estimates for low \u03bc<sub>d</sub> are due to a combination of effects, including an inaccurate lens-model for a complex lens configuration and/or due to differential lensing of more compact regions in the submillimetre continuum compared to those more extended seen in CO.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Secondly, the discrepancy in magnification factors could be related to a poorly sampled parameter space in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}\\text{-}$|</span>FWHM plane for both lensed and unlensed sources. The measured <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> for lensed objects is limited to the depth of such observations. Deeper observations of currently CO undetected objects, might extend the range and scatter of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> for lensed objects. Similarly, the current low-<em>J</em> CO observations of unlensed objects might not cover the full range of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> versus FWHM, particularly for small linewidths (&lt;500\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>) with significant CO luminosities (few 10<sup>10</sup>\u00a0K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>). In such cases, the current implementation of this <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}\\text{-}$|</span>FWHM method may be flawed and thus would lead to large discrepancies for low \u03bc<sub>d</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In summary, our results show that even a rough estimation of the lensing magnification based on unresolved CO measurements is highly unreliable. The large scatter in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span>\u2013FWHM relation (driven by the different source geometries), implies that such estimates will be typically off by factors of \u223c2, particularly when there is independent evidence that the lens configuration could be unusual.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104854 id=\"92104854\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>CO and dust sizes</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Assuming that the CO line emission is optically thick, it is possible to estimate the CO emitting size, <em>r</em><sub>CO</sub>, even if our observations are unresolved. From the derivation of equation <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ2\"></span><a href=\"#equ2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> in Solomon &amp; Vanden Bout (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), and assuming the CO lines have single Gaussian profiles, we find <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}\\approx 1.13\\, \\mu (T_{\\rm ex}-T_{\\rm CMB}) \\Delta v_{\\rm FWHM} r_{\\rm CO}^2$|\u2060</span>, where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> is the line luminosity in units of K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>, \u03bc is the lensing magnification factor, <em>T</em><sub>ex</sub> is the gas excitation temperature, in Kelvin, that we assume to be mean dust temperature within the SPT sample, \u223c40\u00a0K, <em>T</em><sub>CMB</sub> = 2.73(1 + <em>z</em>) is the cosmic microwave background (CMB) temperature at redshift <em>z</em>, \u0394<em>v</em><sub>FWHM</sub> is the linewidth at FWHM measured in km s<sup>\u22121</sup> and <em>r</em><sub>CO</sub> is the size of the CO emitting region in parsecs. This expression allows us to estimate the magnification if there is a good CO size measurement. Note also that the expression for <em>r</em><sub>CO</sub> depends weakly on the assumed value of <em>T</em><sub>ex</sub>, and thus a change of a factor of 2 of this parameter will yield a <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sqrt{2}$|</span> variation on the CO size.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, we compare the CO size estimated using the above relation with the source sizes derived from the lens reconstruction of the dust emission using the ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm continuum maps, where the latter were available (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). The CO sizes appear to be up to 2 \u00d7 larger for most sources; however, four objects appear to have CO sizes smaller than the dust sizes. This is similar to what is observed in the literature (e.g. see detailed discussion by Spilker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"92104857\" scrollto-destination=\"92104857\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=F8WOBMR9pO~vYeqA28-iJeGOG28aXPcDa~kwjiQx0VN87C8a80h7JzBLnTbpsaZlBe5Ib5aQA6iP~aQTC433zRlkd5XvD-trZZG0~R-yJx~yIvs4JsDWxT0HceFOej3ZTtnun8y0yOzGP6guWs9txg0U1cBR3BBoI2kfcNe5xgtM0DWBqBU03uN7G5XWogXmHc5u9adCjPqWqawssL7naSwqmNI6VMszjfChylWESFylcn0GOLn8AuNQ4BQ8JVRvdJ0wMIEksFI8cFShs05wnkOs5o0vZD5Whopyo4rJWOoYLzW3xAKNS7jO1iyK~Y6~T1AGHWYv~zMzhW4~pytDRA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the CO and dust sizes for the SPT DSFGs (see Section 4.3). The red dashed lines enclose the location where both estimates differ by less than 30\u2009per\u2009cent (i.e. CO sizes are 0.7 and 1.3\u00a0times larger than the dust sizes).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104857/stw275fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104857\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=zPlZWtDBtTrKxLy4oScc45tyD09qExWYQMig5IvTwm1BsIau16yZqBO~IkAbn98L~b2doyHuYVQpkpq3yVM6oUEvzNgHeQ9hahIlxBeHGeqCGnjJ~C~RP1MVoIlwgdknYQo0oF5i6w65PhArwPwb15T8pr5L~RNo5uDu9A1-uClleYxBARlKhdT~QwHbzaXVwKzQNFh9C~yHngj5FDPxvfH3YK1ORKAa29Pi0Q6zs-O1VFrPTadwHnpaKyfx8dRj6kin~gXaDEYqJF-Og6n6HqcT8DHIkXs6lDyjcaWtbaAmhJgOZlHOh9Xbtbyl9qcq7wYn3tB6DOwA1gNPrSONSw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104857&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the CO and dust sizes for the SPT DSFGs (see Section 4.3). The red dashed lines enclose the location where both estimates differ by less than 30\u2009per\u2009cent (i.e. CO sizes are 0.7 and 1.3\u00a0times larger than the dust sizes).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=F8WOBMR9pO~vYeqA28-iJeGOG28aXPcDa~kwjiQx0VN87C8a80h7JzBLnTbpsaZlBe5Ib5aQA6iP~aQTC433zRlkd5XvD-trZZG0~R-yJx~yIvs4JsDWxT0HceFOej3ZTtnun8y0yOzGP6guWs9txg0U1cBR3BBoI2kfcNe5xgtM0DWBqBU03uN7G5XWogXmHc5u9adCjPqWqawssL7naSwqmNI6VMszjfChylWESFylcn0GOLn8AuNQ4BQ8JVRvdJ0wMIEksFI8cFShs05wnkOs5o0vZD5Whopyo4rJWOoYLzW3xAKNS7jO1iyK~Y6~T1AGHWYv~zMzhW4~pytDRA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the CO and dust sizes for the SPT DSFGs (see Section 4.3). The red dashed lines enclose the location where both estimates differ by less than 30\u2009per\u2009cent (i.e. CO sizes are 0.7 and 1.3\u00a0times larger than the dust sizes).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104857/stw275fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104857\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=zPlZWtDBtTrKxLy4oScc45tyD09qExWYQMig5IvTwm1BsIau16yZqBO~IkAbn98L~b2doyHuYVQpkpq3yVM6oUEvzNgHeQ9hahIlxBeHGeqCGnjJ~C~RP1MVoIlwgdknYQo0oF5i6w65PhArwPwb15T8pr5L~RNo5uDu9A1-uClleYxBARlKhdT~QwHbzaXVwKzQNFh9C~yHngj5FDPxvfH3YK1ORKAa29Pi0Q6zs-O1VFrPTadwHnpaKyfx8dRj6kin~gXaDEYqJF-Og6n6HqcT8DHIkXs6lDyjcaWtbaAmhJgOZlHOh9Xbtbyl9qcq7wYn3tB6DOwA1gNPrSONSw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104857&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the CO and dust sizes for the SPT DSFGs (see Section 4.3). The red dashed lines enclose the location where both estimates differ by less than 30\u2009per\u2009cent (i.e. CO sizes are 0.7 and 1.3\u00a0times larger than the dust sizes).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">A possible reason for these discrepancies is that galaxies can be morphologically different at different wavelengths and thus the lensing magnification factors for CO and dust could differ significantly, by up to \u223c50\u2009per\u2009cent (Spilker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Similarly, differences in the beam filling factors for CO and dust emission may lead to differences in the sizes derived, particularly for our CO size estimate, which does not resolve the source. Note also that a smaller filling factor at fixed flux will not change the CO size estimate, which is based on the flux measurement, and the assumption of <em>T</em><sub>ex</sub> = <em>T</em><sub>d</sub> and optically thick CO, but will increase dust size estimate, which reflects an angular size that will increase as filling factor gets smaller. However, resolved CO imaging of the SPT DSFGs is needed to infer more quantitative conclusions, particularly since the CO size estimation assumes that the dust-derived magnification applies for CO (i.e. assumes no differential lensing) and that the CO linewidth can be approximated as a single Gaussian. The ALMA dust continuum maps provide the more accurate information about the source sizes currently available. Hence, we do not use the CO sizes in the following sections and only use the ALMA-derived dust sizes throughout.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104859 id=\"92104859\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>Dynamical masses</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The CO line profiles obtained for our sources allow us to estimate the dynamical mass contained within the CO emitting region. Unfortunately, our CO observations do not resolve the sources spatially, and therefore we do not have information about their resolved CO kinematics. However, the reconstruction of the ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm maps allow us to constrain the size and geometry of the dust emission (we do not use the CO sizes derived above). Our lens reconstruction indicates compact sources, with typical effective radii &lt;2kpc (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) and evidence of double component sources in a few cases (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For simplicity, we estimate the dynamical masses of the SPT DSFGs from equation 10 in Bothwell et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), assuming that the gas is distributed in a virialized spherical system, e.g. a compact starburst. This avoids prior knowledge of the source orientation needed for the computation of the dynamical mass in a disc geometry. We also assume that their molecular gas and dust have the same distribution and extension, and thus the source radius is derived from lens modelling. Using the dust sizes derived from lens models constitute the best assumption in our case with the current data in hand.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The virialized spherical geometry dynamical mass estimator will yield a mass 4.4 \u00d7 larger than the one obtained by assuming a disc-like gas distribution for the same source size, CO linewidth and an average inclination parameter. However, for a disc-like molecular gas distribution, it would be more reasonable to assume a larger <em>R</em> (\u223c5\u00a0kpc as found by Ivison et\u00a0al.), yielding a dynamical mass estimate which is similar to the one obtained for a compact gas distribution. The obtained dynamical masses, for a virialized compact gas distribution, are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104863 id=\"92104863\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5>Gas masses</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">One of the most important applications of low-<em>J</em> CO line flux measurements is that they provide an estimate of the mass of molecular gas in a galaxy. The molecular gas mass can be computed from the CO(1\u22120) line luminosity using the relation <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm gas}=\\alpha _{\\rm CO} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|\u2060</span>, where \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> is the gas mass to CO luminosity conversion factor. The actual value of \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> has been found to depend on several parameters of the host galaxies, such as metallicity or environment (see Bolatto, Wolfire &amp; Leroy <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, and references therein). A significant trend was found where galaxies with lower metallicities show higher \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> values (e.g. Wilson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Boselli, Lequeux &amp; Gavazzi <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Leroy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Genzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Schruba et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). A similar dependence is found with morphology, where compact starbursts show \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> \u223c 0.8\u00a0K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup> (Downes &amp; Solomon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>), whereas more extended discs, such as the Milky Way, show 4\u20135 \u00d7 higher \u03b1<sub>CO</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An increasing number of galaxies at high redshift (<em>z</em> &gt; 1) have an independent \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> estimate and current values range between 0.5and5 (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Tacconi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Magdis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Magnelli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Deane et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Messias et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Spilker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Typically, studies of DSFGs have used \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8\u00a0K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup> as found for local ULIRGs (Downes &amp; Solomon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) under the implicit assumption that they resemble compact starbursts at high redshift (Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). However, recent studies have shown that this assumption might not always be correct in individual cases (Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). For consistency with other DSFG studies, we adopt \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8 to obtain the gas masses listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. In Section 5.2, we show that the properties of our sources agree with this assumption. Unless otherwise stated, we use \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> in units K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92104866 id=\"92104866\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104867 id=\"92104867\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>Star formation efficiencies and gas depletion</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The star formation efficiency (SFE) can be defined as the ratio between the SFR and the molecular gas mass, SFE =SFR/<em>M</em><sub>gas</sub> in units yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The inverse of this quantity has been termed the gas depletion time-scale, which corresponds to the amount of time required to exhaust all the reservoir of molecular gas at the current rate of star formation, with (<em>t</em><sub>dep</sub> = <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/SFR). Typically, given the lack of knowledge about the \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> factor, and thereby intrinsic uncertainty in the estimation of the gas mass, a proxy indicator to the actual SFE has been defined as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{\\rm IR}/L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> in units L<sub>\u2299</sub> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows the observed IR and CO luminosities for the SPT DSFGs compared to other galaxy samples that have comparable observations of low-<em>J</em> CO lines. The SPT DSFGs show an SFE range of \u223c100\u2013500 L<sub>\u2299</sub> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)<sup>\u22121</sup>, which is higher than the range occupied by local spiral galaxies and <em>z</em> \u223c 0.4\u20132 MS galaxies of \u223c20\u2013100 (same units). It is interesting to note from the comparison between <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> (<em>left</em>) that with the exception of one source all SPT DSFGs align with the dotted line, which is representative of higher SFE and consistent with local ULIRGs. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> (<em>right</em>) also illustrates this point, and suggests a \u2018deficit\u2019 of CO luminosity output with respect to <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> for more luminous systems (lensed DSFGs are still more luminous than local ULIRGs after magnification correction). While the reason for this is likely that more luminous systems are producing stars at larger rates and therefore consuming the gas fuel faster, it is also possible that in lensed DSFGs the IR emission is being differentially magnified with respect to the cold molecular gas traced by the low-<em>J</em> CO emission, since the IR emission is tracing the <em>in situ</em> star-forming regions whereas the CO could be tracing more extended regions within each galaxy. This has been suggested by recent high-resolution CO observations of two SPT DSFGs (Spilker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"92104870\" scrollto-destination=\"92104870\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=DvMS262AQUiPlJL61VqwhZI0M7AJVwk4pXg8Null30dGU4Lb5pguJ26iy8gYGEgea7en54Jj5~WOqzlLPmnxnJNqZnWL7ydILt74kXj67VhyIohm7wJCA0-ybcppkJsrPUnjoJU4n3NCSYH5eIc982IOpnZPRSksSqF1IwqgAPVIyIg4xjlfyrtUSiqvRg5AAxjURVoNpulgYTdRbK75gopYJdekURAzrRbC5uUYd~srdqfEVi6DU5O14a2W-0UunrnAh3Ccp6Xm-P76vJFeAuTne4DPI187Cc6x9YbJcp~IbDbnCGhvVCeP0x2ksrcr-dH7qIw07wJDiGtJUV9I7Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"LIR versus $L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$ (left) and LCO/LIR versus LIR (right) for different galaxy populations that have been detected in low-J CO line emission (J &lt; 3). Gravitationally lensed sources are corrected for magnification. The SPT DSFGs are shown as black filled circles. Orange squares show measurements of gravitationally lensed DSFGs that were discovered in various Herschel surveys (Harris et\u00a0al. 2010, 2012; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2010; Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2010; Lestrade et\u00a0al. 2011; Decarli et\u00a0al. 2012; Fu et\u00a0al. 2012), while grey squares show unlensed DSFGs (Frayer et\u00a0al. 2008; Coppin et\u00a0al. 2010; Carilli et\u00a0al. 2011; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2011, 2013; Riechers et\u00a0al. 2011b,c; Combes et\u00a0al. 2012; Thomson et\u00a0al. 2012; Walter et\u00a0al. 2012; Bothwell et\u00a0al. 2013; Hodge et\u00a0al. 2013; De Breuck et\u00a0al. 2014), respectively. Blue triangles show measurements of massive disc galaxies at z &gt; 0.4 (Daddi et\u00a0al. 2010; Geach et\u00a0al. 2011; Magnelli et\u00a0al. 2012). Green squares show measurements of local spiral galaxies (Leroy et\u00a0al. 2008), and magenta stars represent local ULIRGs (Solomon et\u00a0al. 1997). Also shown on the left plot are representative fits to local spiral and disc galaxies at high redshift (grey dashed line), log$_{10} L_{\\rm IR} = 1.12\\ {\\rm log}_{10} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO} +0.5$, for guidance. Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>;
