Coppin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Carilli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">c</a>; Combes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Thomson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; De Breuck et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), respectively. Blue triangles show measurements of massive disc galaxies at <em>z</em> &gt; 0.4 (Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Geach et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Magnelli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Also shown on the left plot are representative fits to local spiral and disc galaxies at high redshift (grey dashed line), log<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{10} L_{\\rm IR} = 1.12\\ {\\rm log}_{10} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO} +0.5$|\u2060</span>, for guidance. The dotted line shows the same line, with a factor of +0.5 added.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=DvMS262AQUiPlJL61VqwhZI0M7AJVwk4pXg8Null30dGU4Lb5pguJ26iy8gYGEgea7en54Jj5~WOqzlLPmnxnJNqZnWL7ydILt74kXj67VhyIohm7wJCA0-ybcppkJsrPUnjoJU4n3NCSYH5eIc982IOpnZPRSksSqF1IwqgAPVIyIg4xjlfyrtUSiqvRg5AAxjURVoNpulgYTdRbK75gopYJdekURAzrRbC5uUYd~srdqfEVi6DU5O14a2W-0UunrnAh3Ccp6Xm-P76vJFeAuTne4DPI187Cc6x9YbJcp~IbDbnCGhvVCeP0x2ksrcr-dH7qIw07wJDiGtJUV9I7Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"LIR versus $L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$ (left) and LCO/LIR versus LIR (right) for different galaxy populations that have been detected in low-J CO line emission (J &lt; 3). Gravitationally lensed sources are corrected for magnification. The SPT DSFGs are shown as black filled circles. Orange squares show measurements of gravitationally lensed DSFGs that were discovered in various Herschel surveys (Harris et\u00a0al. 2010, 2012; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2010; Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2010; Lestrade et\u00a0al. 2011; Decarli et\u00a0al. 2012; Fu et\u00a0al. 2012), while grey squares show unlensed DSFGs (Frayer et\u00a0al. 2008; Coppin et\u00a0al. 2010; Carilli et\u00a0al. 2011; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2011, 2013; Riechers et\u00a0al. 2011b,c; Combes et\u00a0al. 2012; Thomson et\u00a0al. 2012; Walter et\u00a0al. 2012; Bothwell et\u00a0al. 2013; Hodge et\u00a0al. 2013; De Breuck et\u00a0al. 2014), respectively. Blue triangles show measurements of massive disc galaxies at z &gt; 0.4 (Daddi et\u00a0al. 2010; Geach et\u00a0al. 2011; Magnelli et\u00a0al. 2012). Green squares show measurements of local spiral galaxies (Leroy et\u00a0al. 2008), and magenta stars represent local ULIRGs (Solomon et\u00a0al. 1997). Also shown on the left plot are representative fits to local spiral and disc galaxies at high redshift (grey dashed line), log$_{10} L_{\\rm IR} = 1.12\\ {\\rm log}_{10} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO} +0.5$, for guidance. The dotted line shows the same line, with a factor of +0.5 added.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig6.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104870/stw275fig6.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig6.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104870\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=ACh0xzjS7pk55pw7JMud3ln8cJfHISV8mYiQzlFmEm1v3rHpmS2ChUkZjs0uead7ZFCr5Spbzh6EIfleAAdiwIjWQXPVwnpEHXwytRoD9zKdwIA6-TCxXpcXU2CuUKxNZFWOjZ44OEbLN4aSNxlq4tpV65N5G4os3z3KNHZBTnk8FEZP8dYpAquvwLkH~sgtf-dYemijXsOYZd1KLTf4lnVnLS6XWiITEahwoAYb5rEMf2U-xQ8CtsoBwlLvjLWa2WlHiNPt6jNGaV3oa-CYDaONKfkv8OtAYoRTlggSbHlcbTIYLnbR1cpCSbyDFMwwFUm7m6UkwT1k6YUnzl395w__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104870&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig6.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\"><em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> versus <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> (left) and <em>L</em><sub>CO</sub>/<em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> versus <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> (right) for different galaxy populations that have been detected in low-<em>J</em> CO line emission (<em>J</em> &lt; 3). Gravitationally lensed sources are corrected for magnification. The SPT DSFGs are shown as black filled circles. Orange squares show measurements of gravitationally lensed DSFGs that were discovered in various <em>Herschel</em> surveys (Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Lestrade et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Decarli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), while grey squares show unlensed DSFGs (Frayer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Coppin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Carilli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">c</a>; Combes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Thomson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; De Breuck et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), respectively. Blue triangles show measurements of massive disc galaxies at <em>z</em> &gt; 0.4 (Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Geach et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Magnelli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Green squares show measurements of local spiral galaxies (Leroy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), and magenta stars represent local ULIRGs (Solomon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>). Also shown on the left plot are representative fits to local spiral and disc galaxies at high redshift (grey dashed line), log<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{10} L_{\\rm IR} = 1.12\\ {\\rm log}_{10} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO} +0.5$|\u2060</span>, for guidance. The dotted line shows the same line, with a factor of +0.5 added.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recent observations of MS galaxies have presented evidence for a redshift dependence of the gas depletion time-scale with redshift out to <em>z</em> = 2, with the form \u221d\u00a0(1 + <em>z</em>)<sup>\u22121</sup> (Saintonge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Tacconi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Genzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). These observations are supported by theoretical models that seek to explain the evolution of typical star-forming galaxies using an equilibrium framework, where galaxies have a steady cosmological gas inflow supply that allows them to maintain significant star formation activity over several gigayears. Such models show that the gas depletion time-scales for MS galaxies should evolve as \u221d\u00a0(1 + <em>z</em>)<sup>\u22121.5</sup> (Dutton, van den Bosch &amp; Dekel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Dav\u00e9, Finlator &amp; Oppenheimer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). With this form, MS galaxies should have roughly constant gas depletion time-scales with redshift, at <em>z</em> &gt; 3. Note that recent results found by Genzel et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), show a weaker dependence of <em>t</em><sub>dep</sub> with redshift (\u221d\u00a0(1 + <em>z</em>)<sup>\u22120.3</sup>) for MS galaxies. While this behaviour has been observed in MS galaxies, both lensed and unlensed (Saintonge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), it is predicted that galaxies undergoing major mergers should have scattered properties, as they are out of an equilibrium state, and hence should not comply to the aforementioned <em>t</em><sub>dep</sub> evolution with redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, we explore the evolution of the gas depletion time-scale with redshift for the SPT DSFGs compared to other DSFGs from the literature with low-<em>J</em> CO observations. We assume a conversion between the SFR and IR luminosity of SFR = 10<sup>\u221210</sup><em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> for a Chabrier initial mass function (Chabrier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm gas}=\\alpha _{\\rm CO} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> and \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8. Neither parameter, <em>t</em><sub>dep</sub> nor <em>z</em>, depends on the lensing magnification. We assume no differential magnification between the CO and dust emission. We find that the gas depletion time-scales for SPT DSFGs range between \u223c10\u2013100\u00a0Myr. Furthermore, the data show that the gas depletion time-scales are fairly homogeneous and independent of redshift, suggesting little evolution of this parameter with cosmic time. In all the sources shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, we are assuming \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8. If we were to scale the gas masses to \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 4.6, which is not supported by our observations (see below), the data points of the high-redshift objects would lie within the shaded region predicted for MS galaxies, but with a large scatter.</p>                        <a id=\"92104873\" scrollto-destination=\"92104873\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=Q3WB~bGT5E3DxQjuba8COoctZGEtn47O9nVSH5HxWu3B6nho4O8R8pIdBzUL6JvasKLHacI1311iDkPGDJV1f-srjVVWwHF7prvv5hIl-6w0qXg079R7tpVT4E--WppJh8~8ge99s7qvsxhOn~j5H25m3qHcMvsAL5qqI9J7Oc5D4f1f6rShH0n72XxunCqMb4Y2sQyge16CQmf67UC4eR3mro7nkaVqP2C-vvzfpyrEdNK7x47ccaiHo-QyBRT4t1q29pRTB-p-8ZIEwEdbGiKYd8Ejx2PAotmGqREZ~ynVSvNNRVpw0fYzsy178JiMZItL~1Ls-HJHUQtmHLpMLQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Gas depletion time-scale (tdep) versus redshift (z) for the SPT DSFGs (black circles), compared with other DSFGs from the literature: local ULIRGs (magenta stars; Solomon et\u00a0al. 1997), HyLIRGs (green diamonds; Combes et\u00a0al. 2012), unlensed DSFGs (grey squares; Frayer et\u00a0al. 2008; Coppin et\u00a0al. 2010; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2010, 2011, 2013; Carilli et\u00a0al. 2011; Riechers et\u00a0al. 2011b, 2014; Thomson et\u00a0al. 2012; Walter et\u00a0al. 2012; Bothwell et\u00a0al. 2013; Hodge et\u00a0al. 2013; De Breuck et\u00a0al. 2014) and lensed DSFGs (orange circles; Harris et\u00a0al. 2010; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2010; Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2010; Lestrade et\u00a0al. 2011; Decarli et\u00a0al. 2012; Fu et\u00a0al. 2012; Harris et\u00a0al. 2012). The shaded regions enclose the curves 1.5 \u00d7 (1 + z)1.0\u20131.5, which is where MS galaxies at z &lt; 3 are observed to reside (Saintonge et\u00a0al. 2013). Measurements for lensed sources assume no differential lensing.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104873/stw275fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104873\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=H-vDVES65rncF~YuyOiYGiyfugHoWr~bH4leBlk7tE4u3h7wuiGS5SIs-RWgQ3NvXAzqO6YgpZtDCjWbGCqVlPo7~EqffpNW-i26YdGSc1Z3Wh58cbrR9TLjZ4vu-2cgOJE3X-N~iTR95t6Qic430aaGfmykwmxpPVzujqLKkg4w~elLTMZ-QelEz5hZf3gwwTDuxsJ5~-QGkVa4i6y4mJV4Ieheho66N8nZQ5pZFJd0Cj5ZVmWka5yyGaR58TjrT2Q3ClV3rBz1RJl4rvXvluOZl1-yIB-Y-cYGYfUoDJyvfTBA41ADQpbh5Z2yx1RF~Iezzi0Xrozfr0PNJZajnA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104873&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gas depletion time-scale (<em>t</em><sub>dep</sub>) versus redshift (<em>z</em>) for the SPT DSFGs (black circles), compared with other DSFGs from the literature: local ULIRGs (magenta stars; The shaded regions enclose the curves 1.5 \u00d7 (1 + <em>z</em>)<sup>1.0\u20131.5</sup>, which is where MS galaxies at <em>z</em> &lt; 3 are observed to reside (Saintonge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Measurements for lensed sources assume no differential lensing.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=Q3WB~bGT5E3DxQjuba8COoctZGEtn47O9nVSH5HxWu3B6nho4O8R8pIdBzUL6JvasKLHacI1311iDkPGDJV1f-srjVVWwHF7prvv5hIl-6w0qXg079R7tpVT4E--WppJh8~8ge99s7qvsxhOn~j5H25m3qHcMvsAL5qqI9J7Oc5D4f1f6rShH0n72XxunCqMb4Y2sQyge16CQmf67UC4eR3mro7nkaVqP2C-vvzfpyrEdNK7x47ccaiHo-QyBRT4t1q29pRTB-p-8ZIEwEdbGiKYd8Ejx2PAotmGqREZ~ynVSvNNRVpw0fYzsy178JiMZItL~1Ls-HJHUQtmHLpMLQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Gas depletion time-scale (tdep) versus redshift (z) for the SPT DSFGs (black circles), compared with other DSFGs from the literature: local ULIRGs (magenta stars; Solomon et\u00a0al. 1997), HyLIRGs (green diamonds; Combes et\u00a0al. 2012), unlensed DSFGs (grey squares; Frayer et\u00a0al. 2008; Coppin et\u00a0al. 2010; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2010, 2011, 2013; Carilli et\u00a0al. 2011; Riechers et\u00a0al. 2011b, 2014; Thomson et\u00a0al. 2012; Walter et\u00a0al. 2012; Bothwell et\u00a0al. 2013; Hodge et\u00a0al. 2013; De Breuck et\u00a0al. 2014) and lensed DSFGs (orange circles; Harris et\u00a0al. 2010; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2010; Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2010; Lestrade et\u00a0al. 2011; Decarli et\u00a0al. 2012; Fu et\u00a0al. 2012; Harris et\u00a0al. 2012). The shaded regions enclose the curves 1.5 \u00d7 (1 + z)1.0\u20131.5, which is where MS galaxies at z &lt; 3 are observed to reside (Saintonge et\u00a0al. 2013). Measurements for lensed sources assume no differential lensing.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104873/stw275fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104873\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=H-vDVES65rncF~YuyOiYGiyfugHoWr~bH4leBlk7tE4u3h7wuiGS5SIs-RWgQ3NvXAzqO6YgpZtDCjWbGCqVlPo7~EqffpNW-i26YdGSc1Z3Wh58cbrR9TLjZ4vu-2cgOJE3X-N~iTR95t6Qic430aaGfmykwmxpPVzujqLKkg4w~elLTMZ-QelEz5hZf3gwwTDuxsJ5~-QGkVa4i6y4mJV4Ieheho66N8nZQ5pZFJd0Cj5ZVmWka5yyGaR58TjrT2Q3ClV3rBz1RJl4rvXvluOZl1-yIB-Y-cYGYfUoDJyvfTBA41ADQpbh5Z2yx1RF~Iezzi0Xrozfr0PNJZajnA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104873&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gas depletion time-scale (<em>t</em><sub>dep</sub>) versus redshift (<em>z</em>) for the SPT DSFGs (black circles), compared with other DSFGs from the literature: local ULIRGs (magenta stars; Solomon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>), HyLIRGs (green diamonds; Combes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), unlensed DSFGs (grey squares; Frayer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Coppin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Carilli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib98\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib98\" data-open=\"bib98\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Thomson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Lestrade et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Decarli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The shaded regions enclose the curves 1.5 \u00d7 (1 + <em>z</em>)<sup>1.0\u20131.5</sup>, which is where MS galaxies at <em>z</em> &lt; 3 are observed to reside (Saintonge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Measurements for lensed sources assume no differential lensing.</p></div></div>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104874 id=\"92104874\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-2>\u03b1<sub>CO</sub> conversion factor</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">A different approach to obtain molecular gas masses for galaxies is to use the dust mass as a proxy for the ISM mass content (Leroy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Magdis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Magnelli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Scoville et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib104\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib104\" data-open=\"bib104\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Genzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). The dust masses can be computed from dust model fits to the IR/submm photometry data. Thereby, under a reasonable assumption of the gas-to-dust ratio (\u03b4<sub>GDR</sub>), and that the ISM is all molecular, gas masses can be extracted using <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub> = \u03b4<sub>GDR</sub><em>M</em><sub>dust</sub>. The advantage of this approach, for high-redshift samples in particular, is the wealth of IR data available for these samples which allows for the computation of accurate dust models (e.g. from <em>Herschel</em> surveys). This method can also be observationally less expensive than measuring CO line fluxes.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">By comparing the molecular gas masses derived from dust models with the measured CO luminosities one can provide an estimate of the \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> conversion factor for individual galaxies from <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\alpha _{\\rm CO}=M_{\\rm gas}/L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|\u2060</span>. In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig8\" data-open=\"fig8\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">8</a>, we show the \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> values for the SPT DSFGs derived using \u03b4<sub>GDR</sub> = 100 (Sandstrom et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), and assuming no differential magnification between the CO and dust emission. The IR luminosities of the SPT DSFGs have been corrected by lensing magnification by either using the real \u03bc value or assuming the average magnification of the sample, \u03bc = 10, when individual values were not available. For comparison, measurements of \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> in high-redshift galaxies are also shown. These have been computed using a variety of methods including dynamical mass estimates, CO luminosity surface density and gas-to-dust mass ratios. Our results indicate that most SPT DSFGs have values of \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> \u223c 1, consistent with other similarly luminous DSFGs and high-redshift QSOs from the literature. Conversely typical <em>z</em> \u223c 2 MS galaxies show larger values of \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> suggesting a different nature compared to SPT DSFGs. This may also indicate a selection effect, where we have not observed faint enough SPT sources to populate that region of the diagram yet (<em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> cutoff).</p>                        <a id=\"92104877\" scrollto-destination=\"92104877\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=x~5VQbf4zsFKg5-SdOYg-qcFEjLMnBMrjDLF9n6tkbboxp1vxjwJGWPoJaSKpZipN2n3v8EAz-ffW9EPSY3PNXW8U7Ud1isWUBLnma-l~zMpyqHvWdqGsOlJ2srJaMXQ0vH~XVvcm0740VE0Nd53JtN9xIYgXI06zuas5IDpodgpyxGAxd3XZErdlLLlS5zn-eRYnmR9P0s60QU-GxN~TEClxAKpm9ZMmJpFkqeyyUqXVNmAZ5t2m0fAxABIxae98Z2J2sLXpfnwlk0fkvv3WURzEnS2Wt~cqRL0CEIhJNOYutVn3LWIuxM1OzlETMlpi2LDNvBjQlUh~yeGtdvAHQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"\u03b1CO factor versus IR luminosity for SPT SMGs computed from the comparison between the dust-derived MISM, dust and $L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$. Deane et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Messias et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Spilker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig8\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 8.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=x~5VQbf4zsFKg5-SdOYg-qcFEjLMnBMrjDLF9n6tkbboxp1vxjwJGWPoJaSKpZipN2n3v8EAz-ffW9EPSY3PNXW8U7Ud1isWUBLnma-l~zMpyqHvWdqGsOlJ2srJaMXQ0vH~XVvcm0740VE0Nd53JtN9xIYgXI06zuas5IDpodgpyxGAxd3XZErdlLLlS5zn-eRYnmR9P0s60QU-GxN~TEClxAKpm9ZMmJpFkqeyyUqXVNmAZ5t2m0fAxABIxae98Z2J2sLXpfnwlk0fkvv3WURzEnS2Wt~cqRL0CEIhJNOYutVn3LWIuxM1OzlETMlpi2LDNvBjQlUh~yeGtdvAHQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"\u03b1CO factor versus IR luminosity for SPT SMGs computed from the comparison between the dust-derived MISM, dust and $L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$. Also shown are literature compiled values for lensed and unlensed DSFGs, high-redshift quasars and MS galaxies (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. 2007; Daddi et\u00a0al. 2010; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2011, 2013; Magdis et\u00a0al. 2011, 2012; Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2011; Walter et\u00a0al. 2011, 2012; Fu et\u00a0al. 2012, 2013; Hodge et\u00a0al. 2012, 2013; Magnelli et\u00a0al. 2012; Alaghband-Zadeh et\u00a0al. 2013; Deane et\u00a0al. 2013; Messias et\u00a0al. 2014; Spilker et\u00a0al. 2015).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig8.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104877/stw275fig8.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig8.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104877\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig8.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=Gdmqa0vri-qqu8kIz0V1etjAC66Xe6ooTIfcUu4saQ0mo70zRZU14JOlYdKTrBchY9e0gt2i2GIKAfbj9c9-v0xmvMFrigYoT5u8pqM2N36W~~L1l4z1ADA9wSjVvDZWNHxJitxwPIlSEk7qFhcQBii7dRIwTbaCYMQ9f1hIM0AtenFrSFspYW5wsVuarf2T3GxBhtQ5qXZS7-gaDdO4qBo02EN~JJEbzUFIup7VOiFGaVoqWypZL-xj~V3JdL63eyEHpYAEZnxyQlAoxNDwndP8Ufrv0WJfVGdoIs7s3vY2h-UMPdKJFCZmLienqNCe99Bo9jh4NSawAhBywi5VXQ__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104877&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig8.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">\u03b1<sub>CO</sub> factor versus IR luminosity for SPT SMGs computed from the comparison between the dust-derived M<sub>ISM, dust</sub> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|\u2060</span>. Also shown are literature compiled values for lensed and unlensed DSFGs, high-redshift quasars and MS galaxies (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Magdis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Magnelli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Alaghband-Zadeh et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib1\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib1\" data-open=\"bib1\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Deane et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Messias et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Spilker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">This method for computing \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> values has important caveats that need to be mentioned. First, this method relies on the simplistic assumption that the dust can be modelled by a single dust temperature. The dust SED may have multiple dust components contributions throughout the galaxy, which are not accounted for in these models. This yields an underestimation of the dust masses and thus our \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> estimates will be biased low. Secondly, if the ISM in these galaxies is highly turbulent, a significant fraction of the gas will have high densities. The \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> factor of such dense gas components will be higher than that from the diffuse emission that dominates the low-<em>J</em> CO lines (Papadopoulos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib89\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib89\" data-open=\"bib89\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Thus, the measured \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> from low-<em>J</em> CO observations will be an average of all components, which will not be representative of the high \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> for dense gas (see e.g. Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>). This is exemplified by the two different determinations of \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> for the quasar host galaxy APM08279+5255. Measurements based on the CO(1\u22120) line (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>), here dominated by dense gas, lead to \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> \u223c 5.0 while and [C\u2009<span class=\"small-caps\">i</span>] emission line measurements (Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib123\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib123\" data-open=\"bib123\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>), related to diffuse regions, yield values closer to \u223c1 (see Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>). These two caveats are applicable to any method aiming to compute the \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> based on low-<em>J</em> CO in DSFGs. Finally, and most importantly, the \u03b4<sub>GDR</sub> value can vary strongly as a function of metallicity scaling to values up to \u223c1000 (Sandstrom et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; R\u00e9my-Ruyer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib93\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib93\" data-open=\"bib93\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Given the lack of metallicity estimates for our sample, we adopted a fixed value of \u03b4<sub>GDR</sub> = 100 for all SPT DSFGs close to the average of \u03b4<sub>GDR</sub> = 72 (\u223c0.2 dex scatter) determined for a large sample of local star forming galaxies with solar metallicities (Sandstrom et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib101\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib101\" data-open=\"bib101\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Since it would not be surprising to find low metallicities in high-redshift galaxies, it is possible that at least a fraction of our sample has high \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> values. Conversely, we should also consider that the increased star formation activity in DSFGs, evidenced by the large intrinsic SFRs, would cause an enrichment of the galaxy's ISM, lowering the gas content and increasing the metallicity, thereby bringing down the \u03b4<sub>GDR</sub> and \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> values (Dav\u00e9 et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>).</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104879 id=\"92104879\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-3>The evolution of gas fraction at <em>z</em> &gt; 2</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">If we assume that the star formation is a process that mainly depends on the amount of available gas, then the evolution of the star formation in the Universe is a direct consequence of the evolution of molecular gas supply (Aravena et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib4\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib4\" data-open=\"bib4\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib125\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib125\" data-open=\"bib125\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>). Recent studies have shown that there is a strong evolution in the molecular gas fraction with increasing redshift (Tacconi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Saintonge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Current measurements indicate that MS, normal star-forming galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 2 tend to have larger reservoirs of molecular gas with respect to the bulk amount of baryonic material than they have in the local Universe, with the molecular gas fraction defined as <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub> = <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/(<em>M</em><sub>stars</sub> + <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>) and <em>M</em><sub>stars</sub> as the stellar mass (e.g. Genzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Using a sample of high-redshift DSFGs, Bothwell et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) suggested that the molecular gas fraction in galaxies tends to stay constant at <em>z</em> &gt; 2, which is well in line with semi-analytic predictions of galaxy formation (Lagos et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib69\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib69\" data-open=\"bib69\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In this section, we compute the molecular gas fraction for the SPT DFSGs and compare it with other galaxy populations from the literature. Since we do not have stellar mass measurements for all our sample, we instead compute the molecular gas fraction as <em>f</em><sub>gas</sub> = <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>, where <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub> is the dynamical mass. This assumes that the ISM is molecular dominated.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> shows the molecular gas fraction computed in this way for the SPT DSFGs as a function of redshift. For the SPT DSFGs, the gas fractions are provided using two different estimates of the gas mass, one using the CO luminosities and assuming \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8 (shown by filled black circles) and another using the dust masses as explained in the previous section. For comparison, we also show the gas fraction computed in the same manner for other samples in the literature, including ULIRGs (Downes &amp; Solomon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>), HyLIRGs (Combes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), MS galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 1\u20132 (Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Tacconi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib116\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib116\" data-open=\"bib116\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), unlensed DSFGs at <em>z</em> \u223c 1\u20134 (Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and lensed DSFGs at <em>z</em> \u223c 2 (Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). For MS galaxies, <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub> was computed assuming a disc like geometry. Where available, <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub> estimates were obtained directly from resolved CO images (Downes &amp; Solomon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>; Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), as they provide more accurate estimates. For HyLIRGs and unlensed DSFGs, dynamical masses were computed using a virialized spherical geometry as explained in Section 4.4, assuming a 1\u00a0kpc source radius. For lensed DSFGs, we only take into account those with measured magnification factors, and compute <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub> using a spherical geometry and a source radius obtained from the lens model (Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation).</p>                        <a id=\"92104883\" scrollto-destination=\"92104883\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=LiMqGVH7oAW10P9JQ2Gb2vd3kgv4seT1p73NfgkC8rUl4Q1fMHpAIU6NmUhu~Xrh0PMfPPFjHU4MTsSPFA4OoUM~NkrPlyf8CLvsWWc7vgDJooGFL9PFo97I6FgMRaCgP-e2gzpFNDMuDzf6cIrgnDBQINPHdhAtxiKz4yVQR1nkQuKlaVLHguvJDQ21WUo6BHFK8DP5LA-yhaK9aOP8HzAVTCg-B5n~cgNNLuXknZuJ~bB4PD-QYirnT44GdXTEwAQaZ9xI4h44wnUBt62jIy~bgEERDTQ2hGvysZ8Jy64X-qov-3CNnra8N7y2SXdWjF13fYNTT3762tzyrwnHJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Evolution of gas fractions for DSFGs, computed as Mgas/Mdyn. The filled black circles show the gas fraction estimates for SPT DSFGs, where the gas masses were computed from CO luminosities assuming \u03b1CO = 0.8. The open circles show the gas fractions for SPT DSFGs, with the gas masses derived from dust models. Also shown are the gas fraction for other galaxy populations: local ULIRGs (magenta star; Downes &amp; Solomon 1998); HyLIRGs (green diamonds; Combes et\u00a0al. 2012); MS galaxies at z \u223c 1.5 (magenta; Daddi et\u00a0al. 2010), and at z \u223c 1.2 and 2.2 (blue; Tacconi et\u00a0al. 2013); unlensed DSFGs (grey squares; Bothwell et\u00a0al. 2013); lensed DSFGs (orange squares; Harris et\u00a0al. 2012). The grey shaded area shows the average gas fraction for massive star-forming galaxies from models of B\u00e9thermin et\u00a0al. (2015). All gravitationally lensed objects have been corrected for the magnification.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104883/stw275fig9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104883\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=l8zQnfrO4kFp5rFaB2JrYE2izJaJEmkV8hSGwpJyGH85pra~SfuW4Mf7yYwRHAPp6mBkbXkHn5KmEjCbRhLDo~BmpDJRbO09VXOn0t9NwIs8ppuPW1LESM1TJh8BMC705CaCAFnFcK-z3fbDNBXeKsNOXr63Li64S6J1worPZ8ypQB2GS3jYTlzMLDjTH-PTp0Kxtad6Ihnrd~JBHWPUFltNVMZC-PNczRuABbMVVKiIR6kjUxsy48uNjl7RELUMBvVfiNDrvIhNh0wOSK-MsRCHVDJTnCMo3p~s-p2-g7ZL-PBihY~9VPMP9isEZZquuNhqyDWOaL66etWuArJe0g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104883&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Evolution of gas fractions for DSFGs, computed as <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>. The filled black circles show the gas fraction estimates for SPT DSFGs, where the gas masses were computed from CO luminosities assuming \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8. The open circles show the gas fractions for SPT DSFGs, with the gas masses derived from dust models. Also shown are the gas fraction for other galaxy populations: local ULIRGs (magenta star; Downes &amp; Solomon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>); HyLIRGs (green diamonds; Combes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>); MS galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 1.5 (magenta; Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and at <em>z</em> \u223c 1.2 and 2.2 (blue; Tacconi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>); unlensed DSFGs (grey squares; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>); lensed DSFGs (orange squares; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The grey shaded area shows the average gas fraction for massive star-forming galaxies from models of B\u00e9thermin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). All gravitationally lensed objects have been corrected for the magnification.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig9\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 9.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=LiMqGVH7oAW10P9JQ2Gb2vd3kgv4seT1p73NfgkC8rUl4Q1fMHpAIU6NmUhu~Xrh0PMfPPFjHU4MTsSPFA4OoUM~NkrPlyf8CLvsWWc7vgDJooGFL9PFo97I6FgMRaCgP-e2gzpFNDMuDzf6cIrgnDBQINPHdhAtxiKz4yVQR1nkQuKlaVLHguvJDQ21WUo6BHFK8DP5LA-yhaK9aOP8HzAVTCg-B5n~cgNNLuXknZuJ~bB4PD-QYirnT44GdXTEwAQaZ9xI4h44wnUBt62jIy~bgEERDTQ2hGvysZ8Jy64X-qov-3CNnra8N7y2SXdWjF13fYNTT3762tzyrwnHJg__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Evolution of gas fractions for DSFGs, computed as Mgas/Mdyn. The filled black circles show the gas fraction estimates for SPT DSFGs, where the gas masses were computed from CO luminosities assuming \u03b1CO = 0.8. The open circles show the gas fractions for SPT DSFGs, with the gas masses derived from dust models. Also shown are the gas fraction for other galaxy populations: local ULIRGs (magenta star; Downes &amp; Solomon 1998); HyLIRGs (green diamonds; Combes et\u00a0al. 2012); MS galaxies at z \u223c 1.5 (magenta; Daddi et\u00a0al. 2010), and at z \u223c 1.2 and 2.2 (blue; Tacconi et\u00a0al. 2013); unlensed DSFGs (grey squares; Bothwell et\u00a0al. 2013); lensed DSFGs (orange squares; Harris et\u00a0al. 2012). The grey shaded area shows the average gas fraction for massive star-forming galaxies from models of B\u00e9thermin et\u00a0al. (2015). All gravitationally lensed objects have been corrected for the magnification.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig9.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104883/stw275fig9.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig9.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104883\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig9.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=l8zQnfrO4kFp5rFaB2JrYE2izJaJEmkV8hSGwpJyGH85pra~SfuW4Mf7yYwRHAPp6mBkbXkHn5KmEjCbRhLDo~BmpDJRbO09VXOn0t9NwIs8ppuPW1LESM1TJh8BMC705CaCAFnFcK-z3fbDNBXeKsNOXr63Li64S6J1worPZ8ypQB2GS3jYTlzMLDjTH-PTp0Kxtad6Ihnrd~JBHWPUFltNVMZC-PNczRuABbMVVKiIR6kjUxsy48uNjl7RELUMBvVfiNDrvIhNh0wOSK-MsRCHVDJTnCMo3p~s-p2-g7ZL-PBihY~9VPMP9isEZZquuNhqyDWOaL66etWuArJe0g__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104883&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig9.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Evolution of gas fractions for DSFGs, computed as <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>. The filled black circles show the gas fraction estimates for SPT DSFGs, where the gas masses were computed from CO luminosities assuming \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8. The open circles show the gas fractions for SPT DSFGs, with the gas masses derived from dust models. Also shown are the gas fraction for other galaxy populations: local ULIRGs (magenta star; Downes &amp; Solomon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>); HyLIRGs (green diamonds; Combes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>); MS galaxies at <em>z</em> \u223c 1.5 (magenta; Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>), and at <em>z</em> \u223c 1.2 and 2.2 (blue; Tacconi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>); unlensed DSFGs (grey squares; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>); lensed DSFGs (orange squares; Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). The grey shaded area shows the average gas fraction for massive star-forming galaxies from models of B\u00e9thermin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). All gravitationally lensed objects have been corrected for the magnification.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The shaded area shows the evolution of the average gas fraction (<em>f</em><sub>gas</sub> = <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>) computed by B\u00e9thermin et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib8\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib8\" data-open=\"bib8\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). These measurements are based on stacking analysis of the SEDs of a sample of massive star-forming galaxies (<em>M</em><sub>stars</sub> &gt; 3 \u00d7 10<sup>10</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>), from which they deduce average dust masses, and thereby converting to gas masses using a local calibration of the metallicity-dependent gas-to-dust ratio (\u03b4<sub>GDR</sub>). It should be noted that different \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> values have been assumed by the different studies, with \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8 for ULIRGs, HyLIRGs and DSFGs, and a Milky Way-like \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> for MS galaxies at high redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using this metric, Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig9\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig9\" data-open=\"fig9\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">9</a> shows an overall decrease in the gas fraction from <em>z</em> \u223c 1 to 0, particularly seen in HyLIRGs. At higher redshifts, the molecular gas fraction appears to stay almost constant within the uncertainties out to <em>z</em> \u223c 5. This supports previous findings by Bothwell et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>) and agrees with the overall trend presented by Bethermin et\u00a0al. out to <em>z</em> = 3.5. Similarly, this seems to be in line with the relative homogeneity of the gas depletion time-scales with redshift. However, there is significant scatter in individual <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub> and <em>t</em><sub>dep</sub> values, which may be explained by the starbursting nature of the sample and by uncertainties in the <em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub> estimates.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">SPT DSFGs appear to have average gas fractions of \u223c0.5, similar to what is found in MS galaxies at <em>z</em> = 1\u20132. The comparison between the gas and dynamical masses can provide constraints on \u03b1<sub>CO</sub>. Assuming <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm dyn}&gt;M_{\\rm gas}=\\alpha _{\\rm CO} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|\u2060</span>, yields <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\alpha _{\\rm CO}&lt;M_{\\rm dyn}/L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|\u2060</span>. For the measured CO luminosity and linewidth along with a maximum effective radius from the dust-derived lens models (2\u00a0kpc), a limit \u03b1<sub>CO, lim</sub>. Individual limits computed thereby are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. In this computation we are assuming that all the mass is in the form of molecular gas; however, it is still possible that the gas is extended outside the radius defined by dust. This is not possible to quantify without higher resolution CO imaging. Overall, these limits imply that a major fraction of the SPT DSFGs must have low \u03b1<sub>CO</sub>, &lt;4, however, it leaves room for up to \u223c30\u2009per\u2009cent of the sources to have larger values.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92104887 id=\"92104887\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec6>CONCLUSIONS</h2>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">In this paper, we have presented low-<em>J</em> CO observations of a sample of 17 SPT DSFGs that have precise redshift measurements from ALMA CO-based spectroscopy. Our main results are the following. </p><ul class=\"bullet\"><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We detect CO line emission in 17 gravitationally lensed DSFGs from the SPT millimetre survey. The obtained CO luminosities imply molecular gas masses in the range (1.3\u20136.3) \u00d7 10<sup>10</sup>\u2009(\u03b1<sub>CO</sub>/0.8)(\u03bc/10)<sup>\u22121</sup>\u2009M<sub>\u2299</sub>. Comparison with the total IR luminosities indicate short gas depletion time-scales (&lt;100\u00a0Myr) or high SFEs, comparable to that of local ULIRGs.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Using our CO measurements and accurate lens models for our sample, we quantified the ability to find lensing magnification factors based on the measured CO luminosities and linewidths. We find that this method is highly uncertain, typically finding a magnification \u03bc to within 50\u2009per\u2009cent uncertainty, in only 33\u2009per\u2009cent of the cases.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">Based on the dust masses computed from multiwavelength SED fitting, we compute gas masses assuming a typical gas-to-dust mass ratio of 100. Comparison of this dust-derived gas mass estimate with the CO luminosities result in low \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> factors for most sources in our sample, with typical \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> \u223c 1. Such values are similar to that found in the most luminous objects (&gt;10<sup>12</sup>\u2009L<sub>\u2299</sub>) at high redshift, and are consistent with the values found for local ULIRGs. Several caveats in the computation of this parameter are presented.</p></li><li><p class=\"chapter-para\">We use the dynamical and gas masses computed from our CO measurements to constrain the average gas fraction (<em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/<em>M</em><sub>dyn</sub>) as a function of redshift. We find that our results are consistent with previous studies of DSFGs that suggest that the gas fraction stays almost constant at <em>z</em> &gt; 2.</p></li></ul><p class=\"chapter-para\">The CO observations presented in this work support the finding that SPT DSFGs are undergoing an active, short-lived starburst episode. These indicate large reservoirs of molecular gas that is however not enough to sustain the star formation activity for more than a few 100\u00a0Myr (the case even if we assume a Milky Way-like \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> factor). This is reflected in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a>, where SPT DSFGs appear located 0.5 dex above the sequence occupied by distant MS galaxies and local, normal spirals (Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>). Further evidence comes from the derived \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> conversion factor which implies a value of \u223c1 for most individual sources, despite the several caveats on this computation. Besides suggesting a uniformity in the ISM conditions in our sample, it also suggest that the ISM has similar conditions to those found in local ULIRGs, for which a typical value of \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8 is found (Downes &amp; Solomon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>). The final piece of supporting evidence corresponds to the recent results of Spilker et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). They perform a source\u2013plane reconstruction of the distribution of molecular gas and star formation in two SPT DSFGs, SPT0538\u221250 and SPT0346\u221252 at <em>z</em> = 2.8 and 5.7, respectively, both included in the present sample. In the first case, their results suggest a pair of merging galaxies with extended distribution of molecular gas, while in the second case, it shows disturbed dynamics.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Even though the current evidence therefore points towards the conclusion that a dominant fraction of SPT DSFGs are starbursts, we cannot discard the possibility that some SPT DSFGs are driven by cold accretion given the increasing number of DSFGs at high redshift with evident disc-like morphology (Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Carniani et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib24\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib24\" data-open=\"bib24\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; De Breuck et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">MA acknowledges partial support from FONDECYT through grant 1140099. JSS, DPM and JDV acknowledge support from the US National Science Foundation under grant no. AST-1312950. JSS acknowledges support through award SOSPA1-006 from the NRAO. The Australia Telescope is funded by the Commonwealth of Australia for operation as a National Facility managed by CSIRO. The SPT is supported by the National Science Foundation through grant ANT-0638937, with partial support through PHY-1125897, the Kavli Foundation and the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation.</p> data-legacy-id=\"bib5\"><div class=\"refLink-parent\"><span class=\"refLink\"><a name=\"jumplink-bib5\" href=\"javascript:;\" aria-label=\"jumplink-bib5\"></a></span></div><div class=\"ref "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016MNRAS.457.4406A", "Tables status": "Complete", "Inspection status": "Incomplete", "Paper Overview": {"abstract": "Using the Australia Telescope Compact Array, we conducted a survey of CO J = 1 - 0 and J = 2 - 1 line emission towards strongly lensed high-redshift dusty star-forming galaxies (DSFGs) previously discovered with the South Pole Telescope (SPT). Our sample comprises 17 sources that had CO-based spectroscopic redshifts obtained with the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array and the Atacama Pathfinder Experiment. We detect all sources with known redshifts in either CO J = 1 - 0 or J = 2 - 1. 12 sources are detected in the 7-mm continuum. The derived CO luminosities imply gas masses in the range (0.5-11) \u00d7 10<SUP>10</SUP> M<SUB>\u2609</SUB> and gas depletion time-scales t<SUB>dep</SUB> &lt; 200 Myr, using a CO to gas mass conversion factor \u03b1<SUB>CO</SUB> = 0.8 M<SUB>\u2609</SUB> (K km s<SUP>-1</SUP> pc<SUP>2</SUP>)<SUP>-1</SUP>. Combining the CO luminosities and dust masses, along with a fixed gas-to-dust ratio, we derive \u03b1<SUB>CO</SUB> factors in the range 0.4-1.8 M<SUB>\u2609</SUB> (K km s<SUP>-1</SUP> pc<SUP>2</SUP>)<SUP>-1</SUP>, similar to what is found in other starbursting systems. We find small scatter in \u03b1<SUB>CO</SUB> values within the sample, even though inherent variations in the spatial distribution of dust and gas in individual cases could bias the dust-based \u03b1<SUB>CO</SUB> estimates. We find that lensing magnification factors based on the CO linewidth to luminosity relation (\u03bc<SUB>CO</SUB>) are highly unreliable, but particularly when \u03bc &lt; 5. Finally, comparison of the gas and dynamical masses suggest that the average molecular gas fraction stays relatively constant at z = 2-5 in the SPT DSFG sample.", "start_page": "4406", "authors": ["Aravena, M.", "Spilker, J. S.", "Bethermin, M.", "Bothwell, M.", "Chapman, S. C.", "de Breuck, C.", "Furstenau, R. M.", "G\u00f3nzalez-L\u00f3pez, J.", "Greve, T. R.", "Litke, K.", "Ma, J.", "Malkan, M.", "Marrone, D. P.", "Murphy, E. J.", "Stark, A.", "Strandet, M.", "Vieira, J. D.", "Weiss, A.", "Welikala, N.", "Wong, G. F.", "Collier, J. D."], "issn": "0035-8711", "custom1": "eprint: arXiv:1602.00652", "Title": "A survey of the cold molecular gas in gravitationally lensed star-forming galaxies at z > 2", "type_of_reference": "JOUR", "keywords": ["galaxies: evolution", "galaxies: formation", "galaxies: high-redshift", "galaxies: starburst", "cosmology: observations", "Astrophysics - Astrophysics of Galaxies"], "volume": "457", "url": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/abs/2016MNRAS.457.4406A", "end_page": "4420", "number": "4", "publication_year": "2016/04/1", "doi": "10.1093/mnras/stw275", "journal_name": "Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society", "author_address": ["AA(N\u00facleo de Astronom\u00eda, Facultad de Ingenier\u00eda, Universidad Diego Portales, Av. Ej\u00e9rcito 441, 8370191 Santiago, Chile), AB(Steward Observatory, University of Arizona, 933 North Cherry Avenue, Tucson, AZ 85721, USA), AC(European Southern Observatory, Karl Schwarzschild Stra\u00dfe 2, D-85748 Garching, Germany), AD(Cavendish Laboratory, University of Cambridge, JJ Thompson Ave, Cambridge CB3 0HA, UK), AE(Dalhousie University, Halifax, Nova Scotia B3H 3J5, Canada), AF(European Southern Observatory, Karl Schwarzschild Stra\u00dfe 2, D-85748 Garching, Germany), AG(Department of Astronomy and Department of Physics, University of Illinois, 1002 West Green St, Urbana, IL 61801, USA), AH(Instituto de Astrof\u00edsica, Facultad de F\u00edsica, Pontificia Universidad Cat\u00f3lica de Chile, Av. Vicu\u00f1a Mackenna 4860, Casilla 306, Santiago, Chile), AI(Department of Physics and Astronomy, University College London, Gower Street, London WC1E 6BT, UK), AJ(Steward Observatory, University of Arizona, 933 North Cherry Avenue, Tucson, AZ 85721, USA), AK(Department of Astronomy, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, USA), AL(Department of Physics and Astronomy, University of California, Los Angeles, CA 90095-1547, USA), AM(Steward Observatory, University of Arizona, 933 North Cherry Avenue, Tucson, AZ 85721, USA), AN(Infrared Processing and Analysis Center, California Institute of Technology, MC 220-6, Pasadena, CA 91125, USA), AO(Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, 60 Garden Street, Cambridge, MA 02138, USA), AP(Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Radioastronomie, Auf dem H\u00fcgel 69 D-53121 Bonn, Germany), AQ(Department of Astronomy and Department of Physics, University of Illinois, 1002 West Green St, Urbana, IL 61801, USA), AR(Max-Planck-Institut f\u00fcr Radioastronomie, Auf dem H\u00fcgel 69 D-53121 Bonn, Germany), AS(Department of Physics and Astrophysics, Oxford University, Denys Wilkinson Building, Keble Road, Oxford OX1 3RH, UK), AT(Western Sydney University, Locked Bag 1797, Penrith, NSW 2751, Australia; CSIRO Astronomy &amp; Space Science, Australia Telescope National Facility, PO Box 76, Epping, NSW 2121, Australia), AU(Western Sydney University, Locked Bag 1797, Penrith, NSW 2751, Australia; CSIRO Astronomy &amp; Space Science, Australia Telescope National Facility, PO Box 76, Epping, NSW 2121, Australia)"]}, "Action": "Scanned and processed all tables", "Status": "Complete", "Publisher link via ADS gateway": "https://ui.adsabs.harvard.edu/link_gateway/2016MNRAS.457.4406A/PUB_HTML"}

$(this).siblings('.ati-toggle-content').toggleClass('hide');\r\n        });\r\n\r\n        // In Chrome, an anchor tag with target=\"_blank\" and a \"mailto:\" href opens a new tab/window as well as the email client\r\n        // I suspect this behavior will be corrected in the future\r\n        // Remove the target=\"_blank\"\r\n        $('ul.wi-affiliationList').find('a[href^=\"mailto:\"]').each(function () {\r\n            $(this).removeAttr('target');\r\n        });\r\n    });\r\n</script>\r\n\r\n \n    </div>\n    <div
