The dotted lines enclose cases where there is an agreement between both estimates of &lt;50\u2009per\u2009cent.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104848/stw275fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104848\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=2PuhkgD3ICaxweFnI7eZ87A8xT5ZYNI0GcdoBupy-8Vg78JC1HF5JtkDuOlQ8y~hJddnVGvmAXLBhXE1ehCB6qT75DdYhKTJeuOkGUfMBlRwXq5HMzPvFveZziVQVEwYEU9FJuYEO2Ena-eqRWjdqoOUlUuiGoJpI8IhR5w~32drbeZFrj60NaWvn5-37q-EmHo~vsANEuYiRof-si4YvnO3aE2KJIzSzLTh8iYQBxU3jdKgnuf6IF~deHRPNzOmJin8PR0RmC8wslQoJhrm857PcMPIN4CaAHOXGZuvQr9uq418qt7n19M9MzmualxTSvmiOIDmPpjTAa3VfOykzg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104848&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing magnification factors obtained by assuming the best-fitting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> versus FWHM line, \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>, compared to the actual magnification obtained from lens modelling for SPT DSFGs (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). Also shown are lensed DSFGs from the literature for which a value of \u03bc was available (Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Johansson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Left: \u03bc versus \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>. Right: fractional difference between \u03bc and \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>. The dashed line represents the case where \u03bc<sub>CO</sub> = \u03bc. The dotted lines enclose cases where there is an agreement between both estimates of &lt;50\u2009per\u2009cent.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig4\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 4.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=RvXvl5xIwydIllZZCp7n7iL0-U8GJLZ68GqpUWRiFeSMh28UTSYp5V628xGAVBOxwFwhMIfu5noL9p~umvHD5L2Gm~WvlBAacwyv-BihlNKHfDYT4ciGOiLCwhqu~mXLKfZ~z66K~vl6Xn67k-xH83-Ye8UL04Bu9RgK28s9TlANRLV30WjDTlImNdJSIUoBOHFDGoTJZ5JuI3uGAgh3cSqfdz~hxgP6WMljsj4bm3Z-U4o8aoa9NS3BCvH9d~CoKu7i-aA3vGHuMqruB26kU6jylSccaVcOesCsG5~h0WU1GHr7rGiZ3zggKZ6aSXaA-dbLOLwZe2sDBQGNo5H1DQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Lensing magnification factors obtained by assuming the best-fitting $L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$ versus FWHM line, \u03bcCO, compared to the actual magnification obtained from lens modelling for SPT DSFGs (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). Also shown are lensed DSFGs from the literature for which a value of \u03bc was available (Fu et\u00a0al. 2012; Johansson et\u00a0al. 2012; Bussmann et\u00a0al. 2013; Riechers et\u00a0al. 2013). Left: \u03bc versus \u03bcCO. Right: fractional difference between \u03bc and \u03bcCO. The dashed line represents the case where \u03bcCO = \u03bc. The dotted lines enclose cases where there is an agreement between both estimates of &lt;50\u2009per\u2009cent.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104848/stw275fig4.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104848\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig4.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=2PuhkgD3ICaxweFnI7eZ87A8xT5ZYNI0GcdoBupy-8Vg78JC1HF5JtkDuOlQ8y~hJddnVGvmAXLBhXE1ehCB6qT75DdYhKTJeuOkGUfMBlRwXq5HMzPvFveZziVQVEwYEU9FJuYEO2Ena-eqRWjdqoOUlUuiGoJpI8IhR5w~32drbeZFrj60NaWvn5-37q-EmHo~vsANEuYiRof-si4YvnO3aE2KJIzSzLTh8iYQBxU3jdKgnuf6IF~deHRPNzOmJin8PR0RmC8wslQoJhrm857PcMPIN4CaAHOXGZuvQr9uq418qt7n19M9MzmualxTSvmiOIDmPpjTAa3VfOykzg__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104848&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig4.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Lensing magnification factors obtained by assuming the best-fitting <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> versus FWHM line, \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>, compared to the actual magnification obtained from lens modelling for SPT DSFGs (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). Also shown are lensed DSFGs from the literature for which a value of \u03bc was available (Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Johansson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib67\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib67\" data-open=\"bib67\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib97\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib97\" data-open=\"bib97\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). Left: \u03bc versus \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>. Right: fractional difference between \u03bc and \u03bc<sub>CO</sub>. The dashed line represents the case where \u03bc<sub>CO</sub> = \u03bc. The dotted lines enclose cases where there is an agreement between both estimates of &lt;50\u2009per\u2009cent.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">The large scatter in the unlensed <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}\\text{-}$|</span>FWHM relationship shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig3\" data-open=\"fig3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a> (about an order of magnitude) makes it highly unreliable to derive accurate magnification factors from CO measurements. For only nine out of the 28 objects with available \u03bc<sub>d</sub> values (32\u2009per\u2009cent of the sample), the difference amounts to \u2272 50\u2009per\u2009cent (i.e. \u0394\u03bc/\u03bc &lt; 0.5 or 0.5\u2009\u03bc<sub>d</sub> &lt; \u03bc<sub>CO</sub> &lt; 1.5\u2009\u03bc<sub>d</sub>). This means that most sources have CO-derived magnification values that significantly differ from the values obtained from lens modelling. Interestingly, for several of the sources with \u03bc<sub>d</sub> &lt; 8 the CO-based estimate severely overpredicts the magnification (\u0394\u03bc/\u03bc &gt; 1). Even if we remove the outlier objects (with \u0394\u03bc/\u03bc &gt; 1), there will be 11 objects with \u0394\u03bc/\u03bc &gt; 0.5 and only nine objects with \u0394\u03bc/\u03bc &lt; 0.5.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The reason why the outlier sources show significant deviations with respect to \u03bc<sub>d</sub> value is not clear, and there is no clear trend among the CO observables (e.g. <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|\u2060</span>, FWHM, signal to noise ratio) that could hint for an effective prior selection of outliers. We suggest two possible explanations for this exceedingly large discrepancies on the derived magnification factor: (1) inaccurate lensing models; and (2) unsampled parameter space in the <em>L</em><sub>CO</sub> versus FWHM plane for both lensed and unlensed sources.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">First, this discrepancy might be related to inaccurate lensing models. Four of the sources with the larger \u03bc deviations, which belong to the sample of Harris et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), do have somewhat peculiar lens configurations as shown by recent high-resolution submillimetre 880\u00a0\u03bcm imaging (Bussmann et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib17\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib17\" data-open=\"bib17\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). More specifically (see Bussmann et\u00a0al. for details): J090302.9\u2212014127 presents one of the most compact lens image separations of their sample, and it is possible that the lens itself contributes to the submillimetre emission; J091305.0\u2212005343 corresponds to the largest background source in their sample; In J133649.9+291801, the optical images do not show a lens source, even though the submillimetre map shows evidence for strong lensing; and J141351.9\u2212000026 shows no counter image in the submillimetre map being thus possibly not strongly lensed. Similarly, SPT2132\u221258 appears to be a compact source in the ALMA images and lens models (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). Hence, it is possible that the largest differences between the lens-model and CO-based magnification estimates for low \u03bc<sub>d</sub> are due to a combination of effects, including an inaccurate lens-model for a complex lens configuration and/or due to differential lensing of more compact regions in the submillimetre continuum compared to those more extended seen in CO.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Secondly, the discrepancy in magnification factors could be related to a poorly sampled parameter space in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}\\text{-}$|</span>FWHM plane for both lensed and unlensed sources. The measured <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> for lensed objects is limited to the depth of such observations. Deeper observations of currently CO undetected objects, might extend the range and scatter of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> for lensed objects. Similarly, the current low-<em>J</em> CO observations of unlensed objects might not cover the full range of <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> versus FWHM, particularly for small linewidths (&lt;500\u00a0km\u00a0s<sup>\u22121</sup>) with significant CO luminosities (few 10<sup>10</sup>\u00a0K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>). In such cases, the current implementation of this <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}\\text{-}$|</span>FWHM method may be flawed and thus would lead to large discrepancies for low \u03bc<sub>d</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In summary, our results show that even a rough estimation of the lensing magnification based on unresolved CO measurements is highly unreliable. The large scatter in the <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span>\u2013FWHM relation (driven by the different source geometries), implies that such estimates will be typically off by factors of \u223c2, particularly when there is independent evidence that the lens configuration could be unusual.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104854 id=\"92104854\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-3>CO and dust sizes</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">Assuming that the CO line emission is optically thick, it is possible to estimate the CO emitting size, <em>r</em><sub>CO</sub>, even if our observations are unresolved. From the derivation of equation <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-equ2\"></span><a href=\"#equ2\" class=\"sectionLink xref-sec\">2</a> in Solomon &amp; Vanden Bout (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib108\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib108\" data-open=\"bib108\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2005</a>), and assuming the CO lines have single Gaussian profiles, we find <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}\\approx 1.13\\, \\mu (T_{\\rm ex}-T_{\\rm CMB}) \\Delta v_{\\rm FWHM} r_{\\rm CO}^2$|\u2060</span>, where <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> is the line luminosity in units of K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>, \u03bc is the lensing magnification factor, <em>T</em><sub>ex</sub> is the gas excitation temperature, in Kelvin, that we assume to be mean dust temperature within the SPT sample, \u223c40\u00a0K, <em>T</em><sub>CMB</sub> = 2.73(1 + <em>z</em>) is the cosmic microwave background (CMB) temperature at redshift <em>z</em>, \u0394<em>v</em><sub>FWHM</sub> is the linewidth at FWHM measured in km s<sup>\u22121</sup> and <em>r</em><sub>CO</sub> is the size of the CO emitting region in parsecs. This expression allows us to estimate the magnification if there is a good CO size measurement. Note also that the expression for <em>r</em><sub>CO</sub> depends weakly on the assumed value of <em>T</em><sub>ex</sub>, and thus a change of a factor of 2 of this parameter will yield a <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$\\sqrt{2}$|</span> variation on the CO size.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>, we compare the CO size estimated using the above relation with the source sizes derived from the lens reconstruction of the dust emission using the ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm continuum maps, where the latter were available (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation). The CO sizes appear to be up to 2 \u00d7 larger for most sources; however, four objects appear to have CO sizes smaller than the dust sizes. This is similar to what is observed in the literature (e.g. see detailed discussion by Spilker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"92104857\" scrollto-destination=\"92104857\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=F8WOBMR9pO~vYeqA28-iJeGOG28aXPcDa~kwjiQx0VN87C8a80h7JzBLnTbpsaZlBe5Ib5aQA6iP~aQTC433zRlkd5XvD-trZZG0~R-yJx~yIvs4JsDWxT0HceFOej3ZTtnun8y0yOzGP6guWs9txg0U1cBR3BBoI2kfcNe5xgtM0DWBqBU03uN7G5XWogXmHc5u9adCjPqWqawssL7naSwqmNI6VMszjfChylWESFylcn0GOLn8AuNQ4BQ8JVRvdJ0wMIEksFI8cFShs05wnkOs5o0vZD5Whopyo4rJWOoYLzW3xAKNS7jO1iyK~Y6~T1AGHWYv~zMzhW4~pytDRA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the CO and dust sizes for the SPT DSFGs (see Section 4.3). The red dashed lines enclose the location where both estimates differ by less than 30\u2009per\u2009cent (i.e. CO sizes are 0.7 and 1.3\u00a0times larger than the dust sizes).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104857/stw275fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104857\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=zPlZWtDBtTrKxLy4oScc45tyD09qExWYQMig5IvTwm1BsIau16yZqBO~IkAbn98L~b2doyHuYVQpkpq3yVM6oUEvzNgHeQ9hahIlxBeHGeqCGnjJ~C~RP1MVoIlwgdknYQo0oF5i6w65PhArwPwb15T8pr5L~RNo5uDu9A1-uClleYxBARlKhdT~QwHbzaXVwKzQNFh9C~yHngj5FDPxvfH3YK1ORKAa29Pi0Q6zs-O1VFrPTadwHnpaKyfx8dRj6kin~gXaDEYqJF-Og6n6HqcT8DHIkXs6lDyjcaWtbaAmhJgOZlHOh9Xbtbyl9qcq7wYn3tB6DOwA1gNPrSONSw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104857&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the CO and dust sizes for the SPT DSFGs (see Section 4.3). The red dashed lines enclose the location where both estimates differ by less than 30\u2009per\u2009cent (i.e. CO sizes are 0.7 and 1.3\u00a0times larger than the dust sizes).</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig5\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 5.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=F8WOBMR9pO~vYeqA28-iJeGOG28aXPcDa~kwjiQx0VN87C8a80h7JzBLnTbpsaZlBe5Ib5aQA6iP~aQTC433zRlkd5XvD-trZZG0~R-yJx~yIvs4JsDWxT0HceFOej3ZTtnun8y0yOzGP6guWs9txg0U1cBR3BBoI2kfcNe5xgtM0DWBqBU03uN7G5XWogXmHc5u9adCjPqWqawssL7naSwqmNI6VMszjfChylWESFylcn0GOLn8AuNQ4BQ8JVRvdJ0wMIEksFI8cFShs05wnkOs5o0vZD5Whopyo4rJWOoYLzW3xAKNS7jO1iyK~Y6~T1AGHWYv~zMzhW4~pytDRA__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Comparison of the CO and dust sizes for the SPT DSFGs (see Section 4.3). The red dashed lines enclose the location where both estimates differ by less than 30\u2009per\u2009cent (i.e. CO sizes are 0.7 and 1.3\u00a0times larger than the dust sizes).\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104857/stw275fig5.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104857\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig5.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=zPlZWtDBtTrKxLy4oScc45tyD09qExWYQMig5IvTwm1BsIau16yZqBO~IkAbn98L~b2doyHuYVQpkpq3yVM6oUEvzNgHeQ9hahIlxBeHGeqCGnjJ~C~RP1MVoIlwgdknYQo0oF5i6w65PhArwPwb15T8pr5L~RNo5uDu9A1-uClleYxBARlKhdT~QwHbzaXVwKzQNFh9C~yHngj5FDPxvfH3YK1ORKAa29Pi0Q6zs-O1VFrPTadwHnpaKyfx8dRj6kin~gXaDEYqJF-Og6n6HqcT8DHIkXs6lDyjcaWtbaAmhJgOZlHOh9Xbtbyl9qcq7wYn3tB6DOwA1gNPrSONSw__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104857&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig5.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Comparison of the CO and dust sizes for the SPT DSFGs (see Section 4.3). The red dashed lines enclose the location where both estimates differ by less than 30\u2009per\u2009cent (i.e. CO sizes are 0.7 and 1.3\u00a0times larger than the dust sizes).</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">A possible reason for these discrepancies is that galaxies can be morphologically different at different wavelengths and thus the lensing magnification factors for CO and dust could differ significantly, by up to \u223c50\u2009per\u2009cent (Spilker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Similarly, differences in the beam filling factors for CO and dust emission may lead to differences in the sizes derived, particularly for our CO size estimate, which does not resolve the source. Note also that a smaller filling factor at fixed flux will not change the CO size estimate, which is based on the flux measurement, and the assumption of <em>T</em><sub>ex</sub> = <em>T</em><sub>d</sub> and optically thick CO, but will increase dust size estimate, which reflects an angular size that will increase as filling factor gets smaller. However, resolved CO imaging of the SPT DSFGs is needed to infer more quantitative conclusions, particularly since the CO size estimation assumes that the dust-derived magnification applies for CO (i.e. assumes no differential lensing) and that the CO linewidth can be approximated as a single Gaussian. The ALMA dust continuum maps provide the more accurate information about the source sizes currently available. Hence, we do not use the CO sizes in the following sections and only use the ALMA-derived dust sizes throughout.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104859 id=\"92104859\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-4>Dynamical masses</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The CO line profiles obtained for our sources allow us to estimate the dynamical mass contained within the CO emitting region. Unfortunately, our CO observations do not resolve the sources spatially, and therefore we do not have information about their resolved CO kinematics. However, the reconstruction of the ALMA 870\u00a0\u03bcm maps allow us to constrain the size and geometry of the dust emission (we do not use the CO sizes derived above). Our lens reconstruction indicates compact sources, with typical effective radii &lt;2kpc (Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig5\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig5\" data-open=\"fig5\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">5</a>) and evidence of double component sources in a few cases (Spilker et\u00a0al. in preparation).</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">For simplicity, we estimate the dynamical masses of the SPT DSFGs from equation 10 in Bothwell et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), assuming that the gas is distributed in a virialized spherical system, e.g. a compact starburst. This avoids prior knowledge of the source orientation needed for the computation of the dynamical mass in a disc geometry. We also assume that their molecular gas and dust have the same distribution and extension, and thus the source radius is derived from lens modelling. Using the dust sizes derived from lens models constitute the best assumption in our case with the current data in hand.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">The virialized spherical geometry dynamical mass estimator will yield a mass 4.4 \u00d7 larger than the one obtained by assuming a disc-like gas distribution for the same source size, CO linewidth and an average inclination parameter. However, for a disc-like molecular gas distribution, it would be more reasonable to assume a larger <em>R</em> (\u223c5\u00a0kpc as found by Ivison et\u00a0al.), yielding a dynamical mass estimate which is similar to the one obtained for a compact gas distribution. The obtained dynamical masses, for a virialized compact gas distribution, are listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>.</p>                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104863 id=\"92104863\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec4-5>Gas masses</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">One of the most important applications of low-<em>J</em> CO line flux measurements is that they provide an estimate of the mass of molecular gas in a galaxy. The molecular gas mass can be computed from the CO(1\u22120) line luminosity using the relation <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm gas}=\\alpha _{\\rm CO} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|\u2060</span>, where \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> is the gas mass to CO luminosity conversion factor. The actual value of \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> has been found to depend on several parameters of the host galaxies, such as metallicity or environment (see Bolatto, Wolfire &amp; Leroy <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib10\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib10\" data-open=\"bib10\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>, and references therein). A significant trend was found where galaxies with lower metallicities show higher \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> values (e.g. Wilson <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib129\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib129\" data-open=\"bib129\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1995</a>; Boselli, Lequeux &amp; Gavazzi <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib13\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib13\" data-open=\"bib13\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2002</a>; Leroy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib71\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib71\" data-open=\"bib71\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Genzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib48\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib48\" data-open=\"bib48\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Schruba et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib103\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib103\" data-open=\"bib103\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). A similar dependence is found with morphology, where compact starbursts show \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> \u223c 0.8\u00a0K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup> (Downes &amp; Solomon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>), whereas more extended discs, such as the Milky Way, show 4\u20135 \u00d7 higher \u03b1<sub>CO</sub>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">An increasing number of galaxies at high redshift (<em>z</em> &gt; 1) have an independent \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> estimate and current values range between 0.5and5 (Wei\u00df et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib127\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib127\" data-open=\"bib127\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2007</a>; Tacconi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib115\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib115\" data-open=\"bib115\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Magdis et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib77\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib77\" data-open=\"bib77\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib78\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib78\" data-open=\"bib78\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib113\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib113\" data-open=\"bib113\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib46\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib46\" data-open=\"bib46\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Magnelli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Deane et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib36\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib36\" data-open=\"bib36\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Messias et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib80\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib80\" data-open=\"bib80\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>; Spilker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). Typically, studies of DSFGs have used \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8\u00a0K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup> as found for local ULIRGs (Downes &amp; Solomon <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib38\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib38\" data-open=\"bib38\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1998</a>) under the implicit assumption that they resemble compact starbursts at high redshift (Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>). However, recent studies have shown that this assumption might not always be correct in individual cases (Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib59\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib59\" data-open=\"bib59\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). For consistency with other DSFG studies, we adopt \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8 to obtain the gas masses listed in Table\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-tbl3\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"tbl3\" data-open=\"tbl3\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">3</a>. In Section 5.2, we show that the properties of our sources agree with this assumption. Unless otherwise stated, we use \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> in units K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>.</p>                    <h2 scrollto-destination=92104866 id=\"92104866\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5>DISCUSSION</h2>\r\n                    <h3 scrollto-destination=92104867 id=\"92104867\" class=\"section-title\" data-legacy-id=sec5-1>Star formation efficiencies and gas depletion</h3>\r\n<p class=\"chapter-para\">The star formation efficiency (SFE) can be defined as the ratio between the SFR and the molecular gas mass, SFE =SFR/<em>M</em><sub>gas</sub> in units yr<sup>\u22121</sup>. The inverse of this quantity has been termed the gas depletion time-scale, which corresponds to the amount of time required to exhaust all the reservoir of molecular gas at the current rate of star formation, with (<em>t</em><sub>dep</sub> = <em>M</em><sub>gas</sub>/SFR). Typically, given the lack of knowledge about the \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> factor, and thereby intrinsic uncertainty in the estimation of the gas mass, a proxy indicator to the actual SFE has been defined as <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L_{\\rm IR}/L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> in units L<sub>\u2299</sub> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)<sup>\u22121</sup>.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> shows the observed IR and CO luminosities for the SPT DSFGs compared to other galaxy samples that have comparable observations of low-<em>J</em> CO lines. The SPT DSFGs show an SFE range of \u223c100\u2013500 L<sub>\u2299</sub> (K km s<sup>\u22121</sup>\u00a0pc<sup>2</sup>)<sup>\u22121</sup>, which is higher than the range occupied by local spiral galaxies and <em>z</em> \u223c 0.4\u20132 MS galaxies of \u223c20\u2013100 (same units). It is interesting to note from the comparison between <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> (<em>left</em>) that with the exception of one source all SPT DSFGs align with the dotted line, which is representative of higher SFE and consistent with local ULIRGs. Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig6\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig6\" data-open=\"fig6\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">6</a> (<em>right</em>) also illustrates this point, and suggests a \u2018deficit\u2019 of CO luminosity output with respect to <em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> for more luminous systems (lensed DSFGs are still more luminous than local ULIRGs after magnification correction). While the reason for this is likely that more luminous systems are producing stars at larger rates and therefore consuming the gas fuel faster, it is also possible that in lensed DSFGs the IR emission is being differentially magnified with respect to the cold molecular gas traced by the low-<em>J</em> CO emission, since the IR emission is tracing the <em>in situ</em> star-forming regions whereas the CO could be tracing more extended regions within each galaxy. This has been suggested by recent high-resolution CO observations of two SPT DSFGs (Spilker et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib111\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib111\" data-open=\"bib111\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>).</p>                        <a id=\"92104870\" scrollto-destination=\"92104870\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=DvMS262AQUiPlJL61VqwhZI0M7AJVwk4pXg8Null30dGU4Lb5pguJ26iy8gYGEgea7en54Jj5~WOqzlLPmnxnJNqZnWL7ydILt74kXj67VhyIohm7wJCA0-ybcppkJsrPUnjoJU4n3NCSYH5eIc982IOpnZPRSksSqF1IwqgAPVIyIg4xjlfyrtUSiqvRg5AAxjURVoNpulgYTdRbK75gopYJdekURAzrRbC5uUYd~srdqfEVi6DU5O14a2W-0UunrnAh3Ccp6Xm-P76vJFeAuTne4DPI187Cc6x9YbJcp~IbDbnCGhvVCeP0x2ksrcr-dH7qIw07wJDiGtJUV9I7Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"LIR versus $L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$ (left) and LCO/LIR versus LIR (right) for different galaxy populations that have been detected in low-J CO line emission (J &lt; 3). Gravitationally lensed sources are corrected for magnification. The SPT DSFGs are shown as black filled circles. Orange squares show measurements of gravitationally lensed DSFGs that were discovered in various Herschel surveys (Harris et\u00a0al. 2010, 2012; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2010; Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2010; Lestrade et\u00a0al. 2011; Decarli et\u00a0al. 2012; Fu et\u00a0al. 2012), while grey squares show unlensed DSFGs (Frayer et\u00a0al. 2008; Coppin et\u00a0al. 2010; Carilli et\u00a0al. 2011; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2011, 2013; Riechers et\u00a0al. 2011b,c; Combes et\u00a0al. 2012; Thomson et\u00a0al. 2012; Walter et\u00a0al. 2012; Bothwell et\u00a0al. 2013; Hodge et\u00a0al. 2013; De Breuck et\u00a0al. 2014), respectively. Blue triangles show measurements of massive disc galaxies at z &gt; 0.4 (Daddi et\u00a0al. 2010; Geach et\u00a0al. 2011; Magnelli et\u00a0al. 2012). Green squares show measurements of local spiral galaxies (Leroy et\u00a0al. 2008), and magenta stars represent local ULIRGs (Solomon et\u00a0al. 1997). Also shown on the left plot are representative fits to local spiral and disc galaxies at high redshift (grey dashed line), log$_{10} L_{\\rm IR} = 1.12\\ {\\rm log}_{10} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO} +0.5$, for guidance. The dotted line shows the same line, with a factor of +0.5 added.</p></div></div><div content-id=\"fig6\" class=\"fig fig-modal reveal-modal\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 6.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig6.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=DvMS262AQUiPlJL61VqwhZI0M7AJVwk4pXg8Null30dGU4Lb5pguJ26iy8gYGEgea7en54Jj5~WOqzlLPmnxnJNqZnWL7ydILt74kXj67VhyIohm7wJCA0-ybcppkJsrPUnjoJU4n3NCSYH5eIc982IOpnZPRSksSqF1IwqgAPVIyIg4xjlfyrtUSiqvRg5AAxjURVoNpulgYTdRbK75gopYJdekURAzrRbC5uUYd~srdqfEVi6DU5O14a2W-0UunrnAh3Ccp6Xm-P76vJFeAuTne4DPI187Cc6x9YbJcp~IbDbnCGhvVCeP0x2ksrcr-dH7qIw07wJDiGtJUV9I7Q__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"LIR versus $L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$ (left) and LCO/LIR versus LIR (right) for different galaxy populations that have been detected in low-J CO line emission (J &lt; 3). Gravitationally lensed sources are corrected for magnification. The SPT DSFGs are shown as black filled circles. Orange squares show measurements of gravitationally lensed DSFGs that were discovered in various <em>Herschel</em> surveys (Harris et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib56\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib56\" data-open=\"bib56\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib57\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib57\" data-open=\"bib57\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib64\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib64\" data-open=\"bib64\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Swinbank et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib112\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib112\" data-open=\"bib112\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Lestrade et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib72\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib72\" data-open=\"bib72\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Decarli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib37\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib37\" data-open=\"bib37\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Fu et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib45\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib45\" data-open=\"bib45\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>), while grey squares show unlensed DSFGs (Frayer et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib44\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib44\" data-open=\"bib44\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>; Coppin et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib27\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib27\" data-open=\"bib27\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Carilli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib22\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib22\" data-open=\"bib22\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Ivison et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib65\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib65\" data-open=\"bib65\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>, <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib66\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib66\" data-open=\"bib66\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Riechers et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib95\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib95\" data-open=\"bib95\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011b</a>,<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib96\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib96\" data-open=\"bib96\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">c</a>; Combes et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib26\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib26\" data-open=\"bib26\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Thomson et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib118\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib118\" data-open=\"bib118\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Walter et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib124\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib124\" data-open=\"bib124\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>; Bothwell et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib14\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib14\" data-open=\"bib14\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Hodge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib60\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib60\" data-open=\"bib60\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; De Breuck et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib35\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib35\" data-open=\"bib35\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2014</a>), respectively. Blue triangles show measurements of massive disc galaxies at <em>z</em> &gt; 0.4 (Daddi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib30\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib30\" data-open=\"bib30\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Geach et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib47\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib47\" data-open=\"bib47\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2011</a>; Magnelli et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib79\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib79\" data-open=\"bib79\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). Green squares show measurements of local spiral galaxies (Leroy et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib70\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib70\" data-open=\"bib70\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2008</a>), and magenta stars represent local ULIRGs (Solomon et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib109\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib109\" data-open=\"bib109\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">1997</a>). Also shown on the left plot are representative fits to local spiral and disc galaxies at high redshift (grey dashed line), log<span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$_{10} L_{\\rm IR} = 1.12\\ {\\rm log}_{10} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO} +0.5$|\u2060</span>, for guidance. The dotted line shows the same line, with a factor of +0.5 added.</p></div></div><p class=\"chapter-para\">Recent observations of MS galaxies have presented evidence for a redshift dependence of the gas depletion time-scale with redshift out to <em>z</em> = 2, with the form \u221d\u00a0(1 + <em>z</em>)<sup>\u22121</sup> (Saintonge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Tacconi et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib117\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib117\" data-open=\"bib117\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>; Genzel et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>). These observations are supported by theoretical models that seek to explain the evolution of typical star-forming galaxies using an equilibrium framework, where galaxies have a steady cosmological gas inflow supply that allows them to maintain significant star formation activity over several gigayears. Such models show that the gas depletion time-scales for MS galaxies should evolve as \u221d\u00a0(1 + <em>z</em>)<sup>\u22121.5</sup> (Dutton, van den Bosch &amp; Dekel <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib39\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib39\" data-open=\"bib39\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2010</a>; Dav\u00e9, Finlator &amp; Oppenheimer <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib34\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib34\" data-open=\"bib34\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2012</a>). With this form, MS galaxies should have roughly constant gas depletion time-scales with redshift, at <em>z</em> &gt; 3. Note that recent results found by Genzel et\u00a0al. (<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib49\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib49\" data-open=\"bib49\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2015</a>), show a weaker dependence of <em>t</em><sub>dep</sub> with redshift (\u221d\u00a0(1 + <em>z</em>)<sup>\u22120.3</sup>) for MS galaxies. While this behaviour has been observed in MS galaxies, both lensed and unlensed (Saintonge et\u00a0al. <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib100\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib100\" data-open=\"bib100\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2013</a>), it is predicted that galaxies undergoing major mergers should have scattered properties, as they are out of an equilibrium state, and hence should not comply to the aforementioned <em>t</em><sub>dep</sub> evolution with redshift.</p><p class=\"chapter-para\">In Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, we explore the evolution of the gas depletion time-scale with redshift for the SPT DSFGs compared to other DSFGs from the literature with low-<em>J</em> CO observations. We assume a conversion between the SFR and IR luminosity of SFR = 10<sup>\u221210</sup><em>L</em><sub>IR</sub> for a Chabrier initial mass function (Chabrier <span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-bib25\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"bib25\" data-open=\"bib25\" class=\"link link-ref link-reveal xref-bibr\">2003</a>), and <span class=\"inline-formula no-formula-id\">|$M_{\\rm gas}=\\alpha _{\\rm CO} L^{\\prime }_{\\rm CO}$|</span> and \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8. Neither parameter, <em>t</em><sub>dep</sub> nor <em>z</em>, depends on the lensing magnification. We assume no differential magnification between the CO and dust emission. We find that the gas depletion time-scales for SPT DSFGs range between \u223c10\u2013100\u00a0Myr. Furthermore, the data show that the gas depletion time-scales are fairly homogeneous and independent of redshift, suggesting little evolution of this parameter with cosmic time. In all the sources shown in Fig.\u00a0<span class=\"xrefLink\" id=\"jumplink-fig7\"></span><a href=\"javascript:;\" reveal-id=\"fig7\" data-open=\"fig7\" class=\"link link-reveal link-table xref-fig\">7</a>, we are assuming \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 0.8. If we were to scale the gas masses to \u03b1<sub>CO</sub> = 4.6, which is not supported by our observations (see below), the data points of the high-redshift objects would lie within the shaded region predicted for MS galaxies, but with a large scatter.</p>                        <a id=\"92104873\" scrollto-destination=\"92104873\"></a>\r\n<div data-id=\"fig7\" class=\"fig fig-section js-fig-section\"><div class=\"label fig-label\">Figure 7.</div><div class=\"graphic-wrap\"><img class=\"content-image\" src=\"https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/m_stw275fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&amp;Signature=Q3WB~bGT5E3DxQjuba8COoctZGEtn47O9nVSH5HxWu3B6nho4O8R8pIdBzUL6JvasKLHacI1311iDkPGDJV1f-srjVVWwHF7prvv5hIl-6w0qXg079R7tpVT4E--WppJh8~8ge99s7qvsxhOn~j5H25m3qHcMvsAL5qqI9J7Oc5D4f1f6rShH0n72XxunCqMb4Y2sQyge16CQmf67UC4eR3mro7nkaVqP2C-vvzfpyrEdNK7x47ccaiHo-QyBRT4t1q29pRTB-p-8ZIEwEdbGiKYd8Ejx2PAotmGqREZ~ynVSvNNRVpw0fYzsy178JiMZItL~1Ls-HJHUQtmHLpMLQ__&amp;Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA\" alt=\"Gas depletion time-scale (tdep) versus redshift (z) for the SPT DSFGs (black circles), compared with other DSFGs from the literature: local ULIRGs (magenta stars; Solomon et\u00a0al. 1997), HyLIRGs (green diamonds; Combes et\u00a0al. 2012), unlensed DSFGs (grey squares; Frayer et\u00a0al. 2008; Coppin et\u00a0al. 2010; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2010, 2011, 2013; Carilli et\u00a0al. 2011; Riechers et\u00a0al. 2011b, 2014; Thomson et\u00a0al. 2012; Walter et\u00a0al. 2012; Bothwell et\u00a0al. 2013; Hodge et\u00a0al. 2013; De Breuck et\u00a0al. 2014) and lensed DSFGs (orange circles; Harris et\u00a0al. 2010; Ivison et\u00a0al. 2010; Swinbank et\u00a0al. 2010; Lestrade et\u00a0al. 2011; Decarli et\u00a0al. 2012; Fu et\u00a0al. 2012; Harris et\u00a0al. 2012). The shaded regions enclose the curves 1.5 \u00d7 (1 + z)1.0\u20131.5, which is where MS galaxies at z &lt; 3 are observed to reside (Saintonge et\u00a0al. 2013). Measurements for lensed sources assume no differential lensing.\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig7.jpeg\" /><div class=\"fig-orig original-slide\"><a class=\"fig-view-orig js-view-large openInAnotherWindow\" href=\"/view-large/figure/92104873/stw275fig7.jpeg\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig7.jpeg\" target=\"_blank\">Open in new tab</a><a data-section=\"92104873\" href=\"/DownloadFile/DownloadImage.aspx?image=https://oup.silverchair-cdn.com/oup/backfile/Content_public/Journal/mnras/457/4/10.1093_mnras_stw275/3/stw275fig7.jpeg?Expires=1611467084&Signature=H-vDVES65rncF~YuyOiYGiyfugHoWr~bH4leBlk7tE4u3h7wuiGS5SIs-RWgQ3NvXAzqO6YgpZtDCjWbGCqVlPo7~EqffpNW-i26YdGSc1Z3Wh58cbrR9TLjZ4vu-2cgOJE3X-N~iTR95t6Qic430aaGfmykwmxpPVzujqLKkg4w~elLTMZ-QelEz5hZf3gwwTDuxsJ5~-QGkVa4i6y4mJV4Ieheho66N8nZQ5pZFJd0Cj5ZVmWka5yyGaR58TjrT2Q3ClV3rBz1RJl4rvXvluOZl1-yIB-Y-cYGYfUoDJyvfTBA41ADQpbh5Z2yx1RF~Iezzi0Xrozfr0PNJZajnA__&Key-Pair-Id=APKAIE5G5CRDK6RD3PGA&sec=92104873&ar=2589079&xsltPath=~/UI/app/XSLT&imagename=&siteId=5326\" class=\"download-slide\" data-path-from-xml=\"stw275fig7.jpeg\">Download slide</a></div></div><div class=\"caption fig-caption\"><p class=\"chapter-para\">Gas depletion time-scale (<em>t</em><sub>dep</sub>) versus redshift (<em>z</em>) for the SPT DSFGs (black circles), compared with other DSFGs from the literature: local ULIRGs (magenta stars;
